story: FRONTLINE NHS staff are running out of protective equipment to treat coronavirus patients, leaked documents reveals.The lack of personal protective equipmentis a disaster in waiting for staff health, alarmed NHS bosses said.It comes as UK deaths rocketed by  to , in just one day as health minister Matt Hancock urged Brits to stay home over the Easter bank holiday weekend.Meanwhile Boris Johnson is back on a ward at St Thomas Hospital after being discharged from the intensive care unit where he was being treated for Covid-.The Prime Minister has been able to do short walks, between periods of rest, as part of the care he is receiving to aid his recovery, a No  spokesman said.He has spoken to his doctors and thanks the whole clinical team for the incredible care he has received.His thoughts are with those affected by this terrible disease.It comes after Mr Johnsons father Stanley Johnson said this morning his son almost took one for the team.The UK leader was moved back to a normal ward last night after four nights in intensive care with coronavirus symptoms.And the death toll continues to climb, now nearing , as officials believe new Covid- infections will peak title: fostering starving girl flat photo revealed horrific truth
story: WITH Britain in lockdown, I cant help but wonder just how many small, innocent children are suffering horric abuse behind their own front doors.Its a trauma that never leaves them - as I discovered with little Stella, my beautul, wide-eyed foster child who was discovered naked and starving inside a faeces-smeared flat aged just four.Stella, a quiet sparrow of a girl with wispy, light-brown hair, came into my home after her drug-addled father abandoned her for days in the pitch-black cesspit, with only dog biscuits to eat.She was in such a state that police were stunned she was alive, I was told.Though the emaciated youngster was initially placed with her troubled mum, she suffered further neglect and soon ended up with me, my husband Lloyd and our two sons, Jackson and Vincent.We quickly fell in love with her warm, trusting nature and glowing smile.Yet as I took out a camera one glorious summers day, hoping to capture some happy memories with Stella, I had no idea we were about to uncover another heartbreaking truth about her past: one that had cruelly ripped away her innocence and already left her unable to bear her own children.Everything had been going brilliantly before the camera incident.Stella, then five, had settled into our family well and enjoyed tucking into homemade meals each night.She also adored rolling around with our Chihuahua-Jack Russell crosses, Douglas and Dotty, and playing a game of teddy bears picnic with our other wonderful foster daughter, Lily.Though Stella rarely spoke out loud, she would often flash us her dazzling smile.On this particular sun-soaked July day, she was enjoying a playdate with Lily - among many children weve fostered over the years - and her friends at our home in south-west England.I smiled as the girls built a den and ran around together, laughing and screaming.It was an afternoon that deserved a snap for the album.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Lloyd, now , captured some candid photos of the delighted children, before I called everyone together, including the boys, for a group shot. Stella was at the front - the star of todays show.It was a joyful scene, but as I shouted Say cheese!, Stella suddenly threw herself onto the floor, pulled off her knickers, pointed her legs upwards and parted them to face the camera.Shocked, Lloyd instantly put down the camera and looked at me.I felt my face crumple, as I blinked back tears.Though we had never seen anything like this before - and there was nothing in Stellas placement file about sexual abuse - we knew what it must mean: shed been sexually exploited.It was a devastating realisation - and one we promptly reported to social workers.Yet it was only one of several signs hinting at our foster daughters horrendous past.Before coming to us, I learned, Stella had stripped off in her first PE lesson at school. She had stood completely naked in front of her classmates, with bruises visible on her upper arms.Then, months into her placement with us, I found Stella had been drawing men with spiky teeth in her sketchbook. One picture showed three smiling men with big, erect penises. Another was of a man with a huge, rounders bat-style arm, reaching down towards her genital area.It was a childs gallery of abuse.Another time, I offered Stella a Lion Bar - only for her to recoil in horror.Though she looked at some foods - like lasagne - as though they had arrived from outer space, she had experienced many new things with us and enjoyed snacks as much as any child.But one glimpse at the Lion Bar and she fled to the end of the garden.It was strange behaviour, yet at the time, we could never have guessed the meaning behind it.That would come from a police investigation - sparked by our reports - which found that Stella had been exploited by a highly-organised, systematic paedophile ring, likely involving her own parents.Barely of school age, she had been photographed naked and passed around paedophiles, while her mum Shannon allegedly used a Lion Bar to control her. It was so, so warped and wrong.Though we will never know the full horror of what Stella endured, we do know she was dumped as a baby by Shannon - then a struggling -year-old mum - and left in her grandmothers care.Her dad Terry, in his late s, was in prison at the time - and when he came out, he took Stella back to live with him in his dingy flat, while Shannon carved a new le for herself where.But unbeknown to Terrys relatives, he had allegedly become involved in child sex abuse images behind bars. Now, alone with Stella, he was perfectly placed to find a child for vile purposes.Later, neighbours would notice a stream of men going in and out of the property.Yet even when Stella was discovered abandoned in the freezing flat years on - surrounded by empty beer cars, her own faeces and her dads pit bull terrier, Sharky - the abuse didnt stop.Instead, she was taken back in by Shannon - whom police believe also became involved in the abuse herself. Eager to make cash, the mum allegedly took Stella on trips to her fathers to be exploited.This will be a living hell for some, she tells Sun Online.I feel for all the women in domestic situations who are being beaten. I feel for the children who are witnessing that. I feel for the children who are being abused right now.There will be a lot of abuse going on.She also says the ageing fostering community is at risk of COVID-, which has already killed more than , people in the UK.I know foster carers that have died of the virus, she tells us.You have to factor in were an ageing workforce. They cant recruit foster carers, sadly, and a lot of foster carers are in their s and s.Louise, a best-selling author and artist who grew up in the care system in Oxford, is currently caring for two foster children.Yet while she says her own experience of lockdown is going smoothly, she acknowledges other foster families will be struggling.Ive looked after children who are deeply violent, she says.I can think of children I have looked after where,they were in lockdown with me, it would be the equivalent of domestic abuse. Weve been held hostage in our own home by an eight-year-old!There will be foster families and regular families who are going to be in a place of hell right now. Exploitation means a betrayal of innocence. It is a sullying of that clean, fresh time of being a ‘child’. There is no way to take that away again - as I know all too well myself.I was also abused as a child: my adopted mother repeatedly starved and beat me. So I know Stella will probably spend much of her le trying to recall, forget, understand and find answers.Her anguish was clear to us the day she finally used her voice.After Lily accidentally dropped some of her belongings, Stella screamed a string of shocking and violent expletives.It was like a scene from Fight Club, but with worse language.Abused children in the care system, like Stella, need to be approached inidually and sensitively.But unfortunately, they are often simply stuck in front of a therapist or another trained professional in the well-intentioned but mistaken belief it will somehow fix them.I have seen rushed psychologists try to assess kids in just a single hour.Its always budgets versus what is actually best - and budgets usually win.In Stellas case, neither of her parents were convicted over the paedophile ring - her mum vanished during the police investigation and there was deemed insufficient evidence anyway.Today, Stella has many physical scars. The abuse she suffered was so severe shes had to undergo operations - with more lying ahead of her - and will never go through pregnancy herself.But despite what shes been through, shes found happiness - both at my house, and with her adopted dad, Danny, whom shes been living with for years and lovingly calls Dad.They are so lucky to have found each other.Stella brought such joy into our house during her months with us.This week, countless other children like her will be suffering abuse under the radar.To their abusers, the coronavirus lockdown must seem like the perfect opportunity for manipulation and control. Who can help their victims at this time of crisis  Who can hear them When this is over, I think there will be a real need for many, many more foster placements.And like tens of thousands of others across the UK, Lloyd and myself, , will be there, ready to welcome a new precious child into our own blended family for days, weeks, months or even years.In , I have no doubt well receive yet more joy, laughter and happy memories.The NSPCC has more information and advice about child sexual abuse - which affects one in  children in the UK - on its website.If you are concerned about your own thoughts or behaviour towards children, you can phone Stop It Now! in confidence on    or email help@stopitnow.org.uk.If you are a child and someone is sexually abusing you, you can get help and advice from ChildLine – phone  , calls are free and confidential.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: channel 4 the steph show
story: Then instead of wrapping a spade round the offending executive’s head and saying: “Try that for gardening leave,” everyone agreed.“It’s a great idea, but the world simply cannot wait. Get it on now.”So there it sits, Monday to Friday at pm. The Steph Show, hosted by the former BBC Breakfast presenter, from her Yorkshire home, with nothing for company but a mission statement: “It’s a power hour of positivity.”An easy thing to claim, an impossible thing to deliver without ideas, creativity, content or anything other than secondhand clips and the same old guestsyou’ve seen clogging up every other show recently.The Steph Show has one thing and one thing only in its favour, though. Honesty.She promised viewers it “might be a bit rough around the edges”, and has been utterly faithful to her word, starting last Monday, when Steph went hurtling round her house to show off the remote cameras and then spent the next ten minutes gasping for air.Over the following  minutes, Skype links maled, mobile phones went off and an attempt to kick off a feature about weird dreams, with Keith Lemon, was shut down as quickly as it started.“What did you ask Michael Hutchence in your dream ”“Things he did romantically with Kylie Minogue that . . . ” “OK, let’s move on.”Had you thought day two was going to improve things, you probably banished those thoughts when Steph began with her own epitaph: “If you tuned in yesterday, you’ll know this is the show that isn’t meant to be on yet.”Or any other day for that matter, although Tuesday’s episode was a technical cracker and climaxed when someone rang Steph’s doorbell, mid-episode. We never did find out who, but I’m willing to bet good money it wasn’t Bafta.And so this hypnotic mess continued throughout the week.Thursday, however, was the day the edice really crumbled, as Steph attempted to lead a mass, safe-distance dancing demonstration, from a car-park in Bristol.Until it transpired the choreographer was at such a safe distance from her CD player it’d be another minute or so before it could start.Honestly, you’ve never heard a silence so awkward or so deafening and it was hard not to have a measure of sympathy for Steph and her production team, who’ve clearly been thrown under a bus by Channel .I say a measure of sympathy, because professional northerner Steph is hardly the underdog she’d have you believe.Her close friend, Sinead Rocks, is MD for the regions at Channel ’s Leeds HQ and, while there’s no suggestion she had anything to do with her recruitment, there’s always an assumption Steph McGovern is “a good thing”.Having never concentrated on her work before I’m going to assume this is for box-ticking, rather than professional, reasons, because, based on her performance here, she’s not a good presenter.For a start, she chunters for Britain, has a knack for saying exactly the wrong thingand crunches the gears during an interview like Jack Grealish heading back to lockdown.: “Provided the last laugh in Germany, did you  What are your tips for attracting wildle ” Eh  There’s more than a hint of The Fast Show about her as well.Absolutely everything is “brilliant”, especially when it’s not. It’s her habit of thinking out loud that could be the death of The Steph Show, though.“Hey! Let’s have our own talent show. Maybe your nan can yodel, your dog can dance.”Or your sister can present daytime TV without mentioning her baby. Every. Five. Minutes. I sense a vacancy in the offing.BASKET-case football club Sunderland and its army of long-suffering fans are trapped in an abusive relationship with Netflix.Every couple of years the streaming service gets to broadcast the most heartbreaking and brilliant documentary series anywhere on television, Sunderland ’Til I Die.In , they get defeat, ridicule, embarrassment and another story of failure told largely through the bracketed series of doom-laden captions that accompany every fresh disappointment: “Indistinct chatter”, “Seagulls cawing”. “Man yells”. “Jack Ross screams”. “Men chant gregariously”, and always “Tense music playing”.You get the impression, of course, the supporters love the attention that comes with losing which, in turn, tends to attract  prophets and publicity-crazed “saviours” to the club. Series two begins with a new owner, Stewart Donald, arriving at The Stadium Of Light along with public schoolboy executive director Charlie Methven, very much the David Brent of the piece, who understands only two things, attendance figures and metaphors and should’ve been ridden out of town the moment he turned up wearing pink corduroy trousers.Improbably, Sunderland also seem to have found a brilliant striker, Josh Maja, who you absolutely know is on the first stage out of Dodge the moment he arrives to turn on Sunderland’s Christmas lights and promises: “I’ll be here next year.”From that point on, disaster’s guaranteed but has to be spelt out to Charlie and Stewart by Graham at the Roker Rapport podcast: “If Will Grigg was the manager’s signing, how come he can’t find a way to play him ”“Um . . . ”BEFORE Friday night, I was convinced a mixture of resolution and good humour would see us through this crisis.No bad thing, but they also need to ditch the host, two guestsand Paul Merton and Ian Hislop, who all appeared, via Skype and remote cameras, in front of their own chosen back-grounds, on Friday.An open invitation to reveal the inner tosspot, they weren’t ever going to refuse.Hislop had a vast library behind him, as befits the intellectual colossus he imagines himself to be, while feminist author Helen Lewis was carefully positioned in front of her new book, exploiting a global pandemic for commercial gain in a manner that seems to be perfectly acceptable to the BBC, so long as you’re left-wing.If your stomach wasn’t already turned enough, the following half hour probably did the job as the four lists and host Steph McGovern cackled demonically at the brilliance of their own route-one puns.“Hasn’t Boris got his Churchill moment now ”Hislop: “Yes. Churchill the dog! HAHAHA.”Nothing, you think, could ever look more sinister, witless and terminally self-satisfied, during this whole crisis, than Friday’s Have I Got News For You.Piers Morgan: “Joe , I’ve reached the point where I may need to join in with your workouts.” .And Piers Morgan: “Let’s move on from talking about ourselves.”Yeah, that’s enough about me, let’s talk about you. What do you think about me Staff at Channel ’s Sex Clinic failing to ask the obvious question of patient Rachel: “I’ve had sex, in McDonald’s, at am, with a milkshake.”Vanilla McFlurry or Hot Fudge Sundae Sent in by Gordon Ashwood, Lisburn, Northern Ireland. title: rooting for pm coronavirus
story: The grim news that he was rushed into intensive care will come as yet another stark reminder that the savage coronavirus can strike anyone, anywhere and at any time.Doctors monitoring the PM became alarmed at his deterioration yesterday afternoon before moving him to the ICU at pm. title: better 6ft apart than 6ft under so stay at home
story: The deeply insensitive mantra of “it only affects the elderly and sick who would have died soon anyway” no longer applies.Prime Minister Boris Johnson may look like he’s carrying a few extra pounds, but he jogs daily, is a keen cyclist and is, therefore, fit by anyone’s standards.He’s also the larger-than-le personication of “Keep Calm And Carry On” — the motivational poster produced by the British government to try to steady the morale of the public at the outbreak of the Second Word War.So the news that he has been admitted to intensive care will hopefully prove the much-needed turning point that wakes everyone up to how important it is to slow the spread of this potentially deadly virus.Last weekend, London’s Brockwell Park was closed down after , people turned out — many of them sun-bathing or in large groups. Today, even warmer weather is predicted.Therefore, with those in mind who clearly think the rules don’t apply to them, perhaps it’s time to tweak the Government’s oft-chanted safety message.Stay at Home. Protect the NHS. Save Lives . . . including your own.If the Prime Minister being in intensive care doesn’t focus their minds, then perhaps the sight of -year-old Ismail Abdulwahab’s coffin being lowered into the ground by strangers in hazmat suits will serve as a salutary lesson that this isn’t “just like the flu” — it’s a potentially deadlier unknown.Whatever your age, gender, race, health history or fitness level, it could be you. And until you have it, you have absolutely no idea what the outcome will be. No two cases have been the same.You could be lucky and only suffer mild symptoms, you might be less so and have a spell in hospital, or worst of all, you might never come out.The latter has been the harsh reality for — at the time of writing — , people in the UK, a figure that is likely to keep risingthose who clearly think that it won’t happen to them don’t start adhering to the strict behaviour codes that will, hopefully, send this thing packing.Or to put it bluntly, better six feet apart than six feet under.ONE of the positives of the lockdown is the rise of socialising via video apps such as Zoom, Houseparty etc.Some people dress up for a party, others have a virtual dinner together, choirs sing, kids have playdates and my friend and I completed a crossword together.But it has its drawbacks too.I’m due to do a chat with This Morning tomorrow and a virtual paper review from home on The Andrew Marr Show this Sunday, and I’m trying to find a suitable backdrop.The kitchen is too informal, with a real and present danger of either the dog snoring or The Bloke wandering into shot in his, ahem, attractive “lockdown shorts”.A couple of noisy, nesting pigeons rule out the garden, and for obvious reasons the bedroom would be a little too familiar.Most online commentators have chosen a backdrop of bookshelves displaying weighty tomes that convey their vast intellect, but thanks to The Bloke’s fondness for books such as The Subtle Art Of Not Giving a F*** and Is It Just Me Or Is Everything Sh** , I’d have to spend an afternoon sanitising ours.So, apologies in advance, it may have to be the downstairs loo.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealCHANNING Tatum is single again after splitting up from pop singer Jessie J.We know this because he’s reportedly back on celebrity dating app Raya, where his profile reads: “And yes, I used to be a stripper. Sorry.”No need to apologise, Channing.In fact, as any woman who’s seen Magic Mike will testy, it will no doubt be viewed as a considerable asset.DAME Julie Walters has revealed she didn’t tell her adult daughter about her bowel cancer diagnosis until she knew she was in the clear.She says she couldn’t “bear the thought” of -year-old Maisie worrying, so told her she was having her appendix out when, in fact, she was having two tumours removed from her colon.“I couldn’t say the word ‘cancer’ to her,” says Julie, , adding that she also “didn’t want to upset people around me. I wanted to keep it small.”In this social media age when certain celebrities post every thought, utterance and ingrowing toenail, it’s a reminder that some stars manage to keep things private too.LAST week I asked for examples of how you were passing your time in lockdown and there were some absol­ute corkers, thank you.Jigsaw puzzles, spring cleaning and garden maintenance were obvious favourites but Pat Ryan painted his shed rather spectacularly and ardent needleworker Irene Threadgoldis planning to produce “  of rock icons”, one of which is below.Well done everyone. Staying productive is critical for our mental health in these deeply challenging times.PICTURED is the gorgeous model Emily Ratajkowski “walking the dog” for a DKNY underwear shoot early in .Fast forward three years and here she is, walking the dog in the spring of Covid--hit .Emily keeping her clothes on.If that doesn’t convince you of how serious this pandemic is, nothing will.SCOTLAND’S Chief Medical Officer has resigned after being given a police warning for driving to her second home – twice – against her own advice.At an excruciating press conference, Dr Catherine Calderwood issued a grovelling apology for “the mistakes I have made”.Hmmm. If we’re being generous, then driving to your second home when you’ve just issued a “stay in unless absolutely necessary” edict to the nation might be perceived as a “mistake”.Doing it twice is, at best, stupidity, at worst, downright “do as I say, not as I do” arrogance.THE Duke and Duchess of Sussex have revealed the new name for their rebrand after the use of Royal was blocked by The Queen.“Archewell”.Of which, under the circumstances of Harry stepping down as a senior royal, there’s a rather fitting, aristocrat anagram: Earl Welch.We needed research to tell us this FORMER F boss Bernie Ecclestone has revealed he’s to be a father again at the grand old age of .“I don’t see there’s any dference between being  and ,” he says.“You’ve got the same problems I suppose.”Except, of course, for guaranteed death before your child is even out of their teens.SOME good news: They’re making another series of the superb Le On Mars, starring John Simm and Philip Glenister.Less thrilling is the suggestion that it will be set in the modern day.Gene Hunt barking: “Fire up the Toyota Prius” doesn’t have quite the same appeal.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus leader of the opposition ask difficult questions
story: THESE are pretty grim times. For those of you who say this virus is nothing out of the ordinary, a big fuss about nothing – how often do we have a Prime Minister in intensive care We all wish Boris a swt recovery. The country needs a strong leader at a time like this and Boris has proved, in three short months, he is that leader.There have been calls for a national unity government. All the parties coming together to see us through this crisis. It’s happened before, of course — most famously during World War Two, when we had a coalition government led by Boris’s hero, Sir Winston Churchill. We had one during the Napoleonic Wars back in , too, when that short French tosser was causing havoc in Europe.But do we need one now I think not. The only reason people are raising the issue now is because the Labour Party at last has a leader who isn’t actually certiable.Nobody would seriously think that giving power to an oaf like Jeremy Corbyn would help us through this crisis.But there are plenty of other reasons to object. First of all, we kind of already have a unity government.The Conservatives have a whopping -seat majority. In the last opinion poll Boris had  per cent of the country behind him, thinking he was doing a good job. That’s about as close to unanimous as you will ever get in a democracy. The Government, then, has a free hand.Perhapsthis virus had struck back in October last year, there might have been a point. Then we had a paralysed government with no working majority.Battling this virus would have been nigh on impossible in such a position. But the December General Election changed all that.But then there’s this. Unity governments are usually convened when we are threatened by a foreign power — as happened in World Wars One and Two and indeed the Napoleonic Wars. There have been brief exceptions.But by and large we have a unity government to show the foreign power that the whole country is united. The virus isn’t a ­foreign power. It is an insentient microscopic parasite. It doesn’t give a monkey’s who is running the country.But the most important objection is this. We are a democracy. And democracy is no less important during times of crisis than at other times. And we need a competent opposition to hold the Government to account. Boris and co haven’t done a bad job, so far. But there are plenty of questions that could be asked. Did the Government react too slowly  Why do our frontline medical staff not have adequate protection against the virus  Why did we allow planes to land from China, back in March, when the danger was apparent.OK, you may think some of those questions unfair. And asked with the benefit of hindsight. But it is the job of the Opposition to ask dficult questions, to challenge policies and highlight incompetency.I would argue that is more vital now than at any time in the last  years.Labour’s new leader, Sir Keir Starmer appears to be a sensible bloke.He is generally behind the Government in its fight against this pandemic.But he must be allowed to question, in public, the Government’s policies.We are no less unied when dficult questions are asked of politicians.The more those dficult questions are asked, the quicker this virus will be beaten.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealLIFE will never be the same again. No, I’m not talking about this wretched virus for once.The Labour Party has got rid of almost all of its nutters from positions of influence.Diane Abbott has gone. John McDonnell has gone.So has the former chairman, the godawful Geordie Ian Lavery.Corbyn himself will be gone very soon.What are we going to do for a laugh without these clowns spouting rubbish all day long Luckily — thank the Lord! — the genuinely berserk David Lammy has been installed as Shadow Justice Secretary.It’s up to you, now David, you dingbat. Keep us chuckl­ing during these dark days.DONALD Trump has turned his guns on the World Health Organisation.He’s threatened to cut off its funding. He reckons the WHO has handled the virus pandemic very badly.The WHO told Trump he was wrong to ban flights from China at the start of the outbreak because it “wasn’t necessary”.He said: “The WHO receives vast amounts of money from the United States and we pay for a majority, the biggest portion of their money, and they actually criticised and disagreed with my travel ban at the time I did it.“And they were wrong. They’ve been wrong about a lot of things.”He may look like a morbidly obese Belisha beacon in a badly fitting wig.He may sometimes talk out of his a***hole. He may have the diplomatic abilities of a semi-housetrained wolverine.But he may well be dead right on this.SOME experts reckon we could be in a state of lockdown until well into autumn.That sounds pretty grim. But there is a silver lining.It means that tour by Genesis might have to be called off.WHO’S nicked all the flour, then  Can’t find the stuff anywhere.It’s aspeople thought: “Uh oh. Armageddon’s coming. Better make a really nice cake. Maybe a coffee one with walnuts, or something. Or a Swiss roll.” I suppose stockpiling flour is more sensible than stockpiling bog rolls. People seem to have given up on that now. Crisps, though, are selling out really quickly.As I mentioned last week, that’s because most sensible people are sitting on their sofas watching Netflix. And you need a snackyou’re doing that for  hours a day.Plus copious quantities of alcohol. One serious point – round my way, it’s impossible to get a click and collect slot for any of the supermarkets.And it’s been that way for two weeks. I know these are dficult times.And I’m pleased the supermarkets are giving priority to vulnerable customers. But would it tax them too much to take on a few extra drivers LONDON Mayor Sadiq Khan reckons that bus and Tube drivers in the capital don’t need protection kits to keep them safe from the virus.With every day that passes, this looks more and more dangerously wrong.There is growing evidence that the virus is more severeyou catch it from multiple sources. That explains the tragedy of young doctors and nurses dying.And also London bus drivers – nine have died so far.All the people selflessly working in frontline jobs where they meet thousands of people deserve proper protection.These PPE kits cost less than  quid per person. Not much to ask, is it I SEE that my home town is in the news.Middlesbrough has been named the place in the UK where people are least likely to obey social distancing directives.This is almost certainly because they think thatthe virus comes anywhere near them, they’ll kick its f***ing head in.“Come near me, you radged microscopic t**t, and I’ll give you a split lip.”JUST seen a report that says our pets don’t know what the hell is going on.They don’t know why we’re home all the time. And they don’t get why we’re so stressy.I tried to explain to my daughter’s hamster, Alastair, what the problem was.“It’s the coronavirus,” I told it. “We’re all a bit worried.”It looked at me levelly for a moment and said: “Well stop Chinese people eating small mammals, then,” before crapping on my hand and going back to run around on its stupid wheel.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: home secretary priti patel blasts top cop snoop shopping coronavirus lockdown
story: Priti, , made the comments while speaking to The Sun’s Executive Editor Dan Wootton on his talkRADIO Drivetime show this afternoon.She came on air just minutes after leaving today’s emergency Cobra meeting and gave her first and only interview since the lockdown began.When asked about the comments made by Northamptonshire’s Chief Constable Nick Adderley in a press conference, where he warned the public officers would stop and search their trolleysthey failed to adhere to the current lockdown measures, she said:  “That is not appropriate, let me be clear about that.“I work with the police and leadership every day of the week and have been since this crisis and leading up to this crisis“That is not the guidance or the measures we have been adopting thus far.”She went on to ask the public to adhere to the lockdown over the Easter weekend and praised the public for their reaction to measures put in place by the government so far.Priti said: “I think what we should say about this weekend in particular, the weather is going to be good, it is Easter. We all need to take responsibility here. This is not about overreach.“We had scurrilous stories a few weeks ago about officers snooping through baskets and removing Easter eggs and that became a trading standards issue.“That is not what the police are there to do. As I said the police are there for public order.“I will be very candid, not everyone will get this right. It will take a few weeks to have these measures bed in.“We want our public spaces to be respected and utilised in the right way.“This is not about heavy handed law enforcement. I pay credit to the police, and the majority of the British public – these are extraordinary times.“But the fact of the matter is,you’re having a party or having a mass gathering do not be surprisedthe police come up and ask you to stop.“The police are using a common sense approach. Enforcement will always be used as a last resort.”In her interview Priti went on to accuse Yvette Cooper of playing politics and insisted she had given the Labour MP a date to appear in front of the Home Affairs Select Committee.When askedshe was concernedYvette wanted to publicly quiz her over bullying allegations made before the start of the crisis, and whether she wanted to deny those on the record, Priti answered: “This is not what this is about at all.“I have offered the chair of the committee regular briefings throughout this pandemic, including access to classied material.“It is disappointing to see this at the time of the crisis when I have already offered a date. There is politicking going on.“When you look at the work of the Home Office during this pandemic, by making  calls free of charge, through the extension of NHS visas, to ious things we’ve been doing across fraud, cyber, national security, policing every single day and the help we are giving to the front line – a lot of that is self evident.“I quite frankly think it is politicking, when we have given access to the entire committee to the department, to myself in terms of another date.“I just think it’s politics basically.”Priti also went on to give up an update about Prime Minister Boris Johnson, who on Thursday night was moved to a ward after spending three nights in intensive care at St Thomas Hospital in London.She said: “He is doing well from what we’re hearing, but we should take great heart that he is in the care of the NHS. We are rooting for him. He is really great, we just want him to get well now.”“I spoke to him last week, around the last cabinet meeting and then it was clear he was unwell and that he needed rest and recoup.“He has been working flat out leading us through this, we need to give him the time and space to recover. We wish him well.”During the interview Priti went on to say the government were considering new measures to help domestic violence victims and confirmed she would be laying out the plans next week.She said of domestic abuse victims on lockdown with their partners: “This is an absolute priority for the police.“I have spent a lot of time speaking to charities and third parties and also the victims commissioner.“There is a lot of work taking place, I have already been resourcing this area. But of course the longer the pandemic continues there will be all sorts of issues around people staying at home and victims of abuse being with their perpetrators. We are finding other ways we can give them the support but also ways we can do more in prevention and protection.“I have been doing a lot of work with this sector and charities about how we can improve our response and get resources out there on the front line in dferent ways. I will be outlining these in the days to come but I can assure you that when it comes to vulnerable children and domestic abuse victims there is a lot of cross government work taking place.”Priti also discussed the increased threats to the public from online fraudsters since the beginning of the pandemic.She said: “I spend every day looking at threats and risks to homeland security. We are seeing all sorts of things but we are especially seeing new threats from online harms and threats in terms of cyber fraud and breaches of cyber security.“As a result there are more protective measures we are undertaking. For example we are seeing a lot more financial fraud online. We are seeing more activity in the space and sphere on online harms particularly around vulnerable people and children and I am working with the National Crime Agency on this right now.“The wrong types of people, perpetrators of crime are at home and are spending a lot of time on the internet, so a lot of work is taking place across the whole of law enforcement, the crime agency, our security and intelligence services as well.“We absolutely are on it.“I will be very candid, they themselves are facing challenges themselves in terms of how they are working.“Across the policing and intelligence community they are incredible in what they are doing but the intelligence they are being fed in – we are actually seeing less crime but they are actually dealing with more crime because they are able to see more crime, perhaps in a way in which they haven’t been able to previously.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: moment coronavirus cop garden

his doorstep, warning him to stay inside as the UKs Covid- shutdown continues.The row is believed to have taken place in Eastwood, south Yorkshire, as forces around the country face questions over their policing of social distancing powers.Home Secretary Priti Patel has urged police not to be heavy-handed while enforcing the lockdown over Easter weekend, with C temperatures set to make Good Friday the hottest day of the year so far.Meanwhile, police are patrolling supermarket aisles today for non-essential shopping, despite a top cops U-turn on his threat to search shopping title: coronavirus idiots flout lockdown rules brighton beach
story: POLICE and military boats are set to patrol beaches on the south coast after Brits flouted lockdown rules in C heat yesterday. Good Friday’s warm weather proved to to be too tempting for some who ignored government guidance to flock to the beach and bask in the sun.Dozens of people hit the beach in record temperatures, some in large groups, despite repeated warnings from authorities not to do so.According to Paul Netherton, deputy chief constable of Devon and Cornwall, the force is looking at deploying boats off the coast as beaches were flooded with sunbathers yesterday.It comes after cops were criticised for going too far after an officer told a family they couldnt use their front garden during the coronavirus lockdown.Cambridge Police were also slammed for snooping on trollies in the supermarket.A video taken yesterday in Sussex showed dozens of people on Brighton beach taking advantage of the soaring temperatures.But, despite the summer-like weather, the public have been urged by authorities not to be tempted to flout the rules and be out of their homes for longer than necessary.The coronavirus has infected more than , people nationwide and killed over ,, with a daily death toll in the UK of  reported earlier today.It comes as:At yesterdays No press conference, Englands Chief Nursing Officer Ruth May said she had seen large groups gathering in London today and was extremely frustrated by pictures emerging from around the country.She said: Its very, very frustrating, personally frustrating to see people clearly not doing social distancing and coming out in large groups.Theres also still occasions where my colleagues are getting abuse from their neighbours for driving off to workOur nurses need to be able to get to work, but I ask of everyone please stay at home, save lives and protect my staff.Health Secretary Matt Hancock added: We must all play our part. Spreading the virus today risks lives tomorrow.Brighton resident, Dean Roberts, said he was furious after seeing hundreds of people sitting down and sunbathing on the beach.People just dont realise the dangers, he fumed.I get that the weather is nice, but there are strict lockdown rules in place and we should be abiding by them, not breaking them.Police are going in convoys shouting through a megaphone to get people away from the sea.The only thing thats gonna stop people from heading down there isthe police start handing out fines.Another Brighton local, Jimmy Muitt, added: I was cycling along the seafront and noticed hundreds of people walking up and down the beach without a care in the world.I take it the Governments staying at home statement doesnt apply to these selfish people.People who drive to the beach or have a picnic could be fined up to £ or even be arrested.As temperatures hit C, according to the Met Office, in parts of the country — police have warned people not to use the weather as an excuse to break the lockdown rules.While it is okay to visit your nearby beach to exercise or walk across, anyone travelling further than their local area or visiting to sit or meet in large groups are breaking the law.Elsewhere, park-users have been seen tearing down do not use signs on an outdoor gym — ignoring safety warnings so they could workout in the sunshine.Red-and-white warning tape was wrapped around exercise stations telling people not to use them because of coronavirus dangers.But the tape was ripped so the foolish fitness fans could do their with pull-ups, sit-ups and dips at Roath Park — and police had to be called to stop them.Current rules mean police are able to issue £ fines on-the-spot for anyone breaking the rules.This can be reduced to £paid within  days.However, repeat offenders will face much steeper charges, with the fine doubling to £ for a second offence, and continuing to double up to £.Anyone who refuses to give their name and address to avoid being fined could face arrest.Meanwhile, in Bournemouth, the beach was eerily empty as Dorset Police urged people to stay at home with the beach is closed to sunseekers.Chief Constable James Vaughan, of Dorset Police, said: Like other tourist areas, Dorset is currently closed to visitors while we do all we can to stop the spread of the terrible virus.In a chilling comparison, Bournemouths idyllic sandy beach was packed full of people last year, compared to none today.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus nurse reveals ppe sores
story: Aimée Goold, from East Retford, Notts, described working at UK’s covid- frontline as going “through hell” in an emotional Facebook post.The nurse, who works at Doncaster and Bassetlaw Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust, shared a picture of her face covered in red marks and blotches from hours of working in the protective mask.She also described the long shts NHS workers are pulling – revealing how she had worked  hours over the last  days.Amiee posted thre status to stop people from going out and flouting lockdown rules over the Easter weekend.She wrote: “When youre tempted to go out this Easter, remember this face.“This is the face going through hell.“This is the face full of pressure damage from wearing PPE for almost  hours a day.“This is the face of someone who hasnt seen their own family for nearly a month.“This is the face of someone who holds your dying family members hand, so theyre never alone.”Amiee finished her post by saying: “This is the face of an ICU nurse that is begging you: to stay inside, protect us, protect the NHS and help us save lives.”Amiees message comes as the government has announced it was launching a publicity drive over the bank holiday weekend to get the public to follow the lockdown guidelines over East weekend.Concerning figures show the number of hospital patients in the UK who had died after testing positive for Covid- had risen to , as of pm on Wednesday - an increase of  on the previous day.At the daily No  press conference, Mr Raab acknowledged that it was hard for to stay indoors over Easter, but he urged them to show restraint amid signs the measures were having an impact.He said: The deaths are still rising and we havent yet reached the peak of the virus. So its still too early to lt the measures that we put in place.We must stick to the plan and we must continue to be guided by the science.Sir Patrick Vallance, the Governments chief scientic adviser, said measures were breaking transmission of the disease with signs of a flattening off in the numbers of new cases and hospital admissions.However, he warned the numbers of deaths would continue to rise for a few weeks and that it was too soon to relax social-distancing.It is incredibly important that we continue to do what we are doing, he said.The chief medical officer, Professor Chris Whitty, said that while the numbers admitted to intensive care had been doubling every three days, that had now slowed.This is really now becoming not quite flat, but the doubling time is now six or more days in almost everywhere in the country and extending in time, he said.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappeal

title: lockdown louts france jet escort
story: RICH City of London lockdown louts have been kicked out of France after taking a private jet to a holiday villa to romp with escort girls.Seven men in their s and s and three women in their s were stopped by outraged French police after their jet touched down at Marseille-Provence airport.The men — all said to be City types working in the UK — planned to lock down in a Cannes villa with the women.But French police refused to let them disembark from the £ million Embraer Legacy jet because they did not have “a valid reason for travel” - and ordered it to fly back to the UK.The group was led by a Croatian man plus his German, French, Romanian and Ukrainian pals. No Brits were on board.A police source told the BFM news outlet: They had planned to come and have a good time on the Riviera despite the coronavirus epidemic.Everything had been planned by the organiser of the trip...starting with the London-Marseille trip in a private jet that he had rented on the other side of the Channel.He then booked a luxury villa in Cannes. To get there, the man had reserved three helicopters from a company which provides private connections for privileged customers.Commercial flights are greatly reduced at airports across Europe at the moment, and the authorities are trying to stop private jets breaking restrictions.The source reported that police guarding the borders of Marseille-Provence airport asked the private jet not to come and land on its tarmac.But the plane still landed anyway, and the passengers were not allowed to leave the aircraft.The private jet used by the groups was an Embraer Legacy - a Brazilian made luxury business jet.Controlled by the border police and the gendarmerie of air transport, none had valid reasons for traveling, said the source.Crossing borders is only allowed with a legitimate or compelling reason.As well as Croatian, the other travellers were German, French, Romanian and Ukrainian, said the source.They initially argued with police, and expressed anger when three helicopters waiting for them were ordered to leave empty, and their pilots fined for breaking lockdown restrictions.The source said the Croatian had paid for everything, including the villa and plane, was  looking forward to the break, with his friends and young female escorts.When confronted by police, he offered them cash, saying: ‘I have money, let’s talk,’ said the police source.The source added: He said they all go to the villa, and lockdown there, and that there would be no problem.But it was obviously a recreational trip, and under the containment measures these are strictly prohibited.’The only fines issued were to the three French helicopter pilots.None of those on board have yet been identied by police.Nine members of the holiday party ed to London by the private jet on Saturday evening, while the tenth went back to Germany.France has been in lockdown since March  in a bid to slow the spread of the pandemic, with only essential trips allowed that must be justied with a signed piece of paper.Health director Jérôme Salomon said the lockdown was working: ‘Thanks to these measures, we are in the process of putting the brakes on the epidemic.’The lockdown, which was supposed to run until April , will be extended beyond that date, it was announced on Wednesday.President Emmanuel Macron will discuss the coronavirus situation in a live TV address to the nation on Monday.     Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mild coronavirus symptoms toilet
story: IT may feel like weve known about coronavirus for a long time now - but its still only a been around four months.Scientists are still working to understand it but by this stage we do know the main symptoms - a new or persistent dry cough and a fever.But experts say there are a few other indicators that could suggest that you might have caught Covid-.And one of them involves going to the toilet.While there is no normal amount you should need to poop every day, needing more than usual could be an early sign of coronavirus.Doctor  U GP Dr Diana Gall explained to the Express: Digestion problems and changes in bowel habits - particularly looser stools and making more frequent trips to the toilet - are sometimes the first signs that you’re coming down with something, not just with this coronavirus.However, diarrhoea has been reported as an early symptom in patients who have later tested positive for COVID-.A new study, published in the American Journal of Gastroenterology, analysed data  patients with Covid- in China’s Hubei province and found nearly  per cent had diarrhoea, vomiting or abdominal pain.Isla Haslam, , from Balham, South West London, was someone who also experienced stomach troubles whilst battling coronavirus.She told The Sun Online that she initially woke up with a dodgy stomach, but thought it was from her dinner of lentils and beans the night before.But by the following day, she had developed a tickle in her throat and felt exhausted before attempting to rest at home.She explained: Waking up in the middle of the night, I noticed my nose was blocked and I felt horric. My body ached severely, I felt so heavy and was sweating with a fever.Doctors have warned that a loss of taste or smell could also be a sign of coronavirus.The British Association of Otorhinolaryngology, which represents experts in ear, nose and throat medicine, explained that an eye infection conjunctivitis may also be another sign.In a statement, the docs said: Evidence from other countries that the entry point for the coronavirus is often in the eyes, nose and throat areas.A study published in JAMA Ophthalmology found that . per cent of  patients with COVID- at a hospital in the Hubei province had eye-related symptoms - although further studies are needed on a larger scale.A number of people who go on to have coronavirus first report losing their sense of smell or tasteIts thought that losing the ability to smell or taste could be due to the virus destroying cells in the nose and throat.Experts say its something people can commonly experience after having other types of coronaviruses - such as the common cold.Prof Carl Philpott, of the Norwich Medical School at UEA, said: Coronaviruses have previously been associated with what we refer to as post-viral olfactory loss– this is smell loss that persists after a cold.There are many respiratory viruses that can potentially cause problems with the smell receptors.So far with Covid-, the smell loss appears to be transient but only as time elapses will we know how many people have a more permanent loss.Ryan Van Waterschoot ended up in hospital for  days with coronavirus, and losing his sense of smell and taste were the first few symptoms.Just a day after losing the two senses, he went from feeling tired to not being able to move in just one day, before his temperature soared and he was rushed to hospital, where he was given oxygen for five days.The -year-old said: I didn’t think I was going to make it out of the hospital. I thought it was the end of the road for me.Some people may experience brain fog, also known as mental fatigue, as another symptom of coronavirus.Its not been officially looked into as a symptom but its another indicator that those who have experienced the illness have reported experiencing.Thea Jourdan, , said she didnt experience a cough or fever - instead her introduction to Covid- began with a tickle in her throat and a dull headache,.The mum-of-three, from Hampshire, says she then started to experience brain fog.She told the Daily Mail: Initially I felt exhausted, asI was dragging myself through treacle and had no choice but to go to my bed. I had no meaningful cough and I wasn’t running a fever.But I had a peculiar sensation of something settling deep within my lungs, almost like breathing in talcum powder.I also had brain fog. I was unable even to fill out forms from the children’s schools. I just wanted to sleep.Another woman, who had recently recovered from Covid-, told the Huffington Post that she too had experienced the unusual mental block before her symptoms worsened.Christy, from Seattle, had a similar feeing of brain fog - she said her illness started with a multi-day fever that progressed into sinus congestion and a headache following it.She added: “It’s not just a cold. I’m pretty healthy and not old , and it kicked my a**.”Another symptom that coronavirus patients have reported is feeling extremely tired before symptoms develop.According to a report in the Journal of the American Medical Association, up to  per cent of those hospitalised with Covid- reported exhaustion and fatigue.Linda Carr, , from Hethersett, Norfolk, told the Mail: I felt very sick and terribly fatigued. But I didn’t have a temperature or a cough.Within two days I could barely stand. I didn’t have the energy to lt one foot in front of the other.But she knew it was more serious than a flu when she developed a tightness in her chest that left her short of breath.After visiting her GP, she was sent straight to hospital where she was kept for five days after testing positive.Linda says she is still feeling weak and remains in isolation at home.Those who develop minor symptoms such as a high temperature or continuous cough should self-isolate for seven days.If you live with others, you should also stay at home for  days from the day the first person started showing symptoms.Anyone with suspected coronavirus who becomes seriously ill should call  and in a medical emergency always call .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus lockdown wuhan mcdonalds queue
story: HUGE queues of people outside a McDonald’s in Wuhan have been spotted after the coronavirus lockdown was lted.Russian expat Darya Kuznetsova, who lives in Wuhan in the eastern Chinese province of Hubei, shared the video on her Instagram account.Filmed after the lockdown was lted following nearly three months of strict quarantine, the footage shows a long queue of people, all apparently wearing face masks, filing out of a McDonald’s restaurant and onto the pavement.According to Darya, the McDonald’s restaurant has become the most popular place in the city and has been mobbed ever since people were first let outside.She said: “McDonald’s is now the busiest place in the city. Such long queues. The very first day they reopened online orders, their system went down.”Darya also explained that the city is awakening from its slumber bit by bit and that the streets and pavements are continually getting busier.Wuhan was locked down on January  to prevent the spread of Covid- where the virus is believed to have originated late last year.There have been , confirmed cases of the coronavirus in China with , deaths and , recoveries, according to the Johns Hopkins University.Official figures for Russia are , cases with  deaths and  recoveries.

title: ireland lockdown extended
story: IRELAND is extending its lockdown until May , while England remains in limbo on when theirs will be lted.Taoiseach Leo Varadkar has announced today the current restrictions on movement in Ireland will be extended beyond Easter Sunday. The current lockdown will now last until May , but Mr Varadkar said it would be subject to review.It comes as the pressure is mounting in England for the government to reveal their exit strategy.The UK went into lockdown on March  and said it would review the measures every three weeks.Ministers have been reluctant to lt the strict measures after Dominic Raab – filling in for Boris Johnson - warned yesterday it was still too early for social distancing to be lted.And epidemiologist Professor Neil Ferguson, of Imperial College London, said “definitive” proof of whether the nationwide-lockdown has worked will take “several more weeks”.He explained: “It is only when we see the case numbers come down and how quickly transmissions have been reduced we can really conclude anything about what happens next, when these measures can be relaxed”.It is believed that less than  per cent of the population has had the virus and Mr Raab said that discussing a route out of lockdown would be a “distraction”.Government sources revealed yesterday the first expected moved “is most likely the re-opening of schools so parents are able to go back to work”.Mr Varadkar said today he was not willing to reopen schools until health officials said it was safe to do so.In Wales, First Minister Mark Drakeford said on Wednesday that lockdown will be title: singapore second coronavirus country model new cases
story: SINGAPORE has seen a dramatic rise in coronavirus cases having previously been touted as a model for other countries in its handling of the outbreak. The country, which has a population of only six million, registered  new cases yesterday after reporting  on Thursday - its biggest daily jump so far.The country has seen , cases and seven deaths since registering its first case of coronavirus on January , earlier than many countries in Europe.Its early, swt response to the virus led to its strategy being seen as a potential model for other countries, but it is now seeing cases begin to climb.The virus is thought to be spreading fastest among the hundreds of thousands of migrant workers living in crowded dormitories where it is not possible to practice social distancing.The issue is of broader concern because a number of countries in the region have large communities of migrant workers living and commuting at close quarters.In Singapore, migrants account for over a third of the workforce, with over , from Pakistan, Bangladesh, and other lower-income countries living in  registered dormitories across the country.Most work in construction, shipping, and maintenance jobs, helping to support the city states trade-reliant economy.Clusters of people testing positive for the virus have emerged in nine of the dorms.More than , are now being quarantined, while others are being moved to safer locations.Some are being moved to segregated facilities at army camps, where they will be required to observe strict health measures, stagger their meal times, and practice social distancing.Others are to be moved into unoccupied housing estates, an exhibition centre, and other locations to help reduce crowding.Those being quarantined are staying at five dormitories that have been declared isolation areas and are being sanitised daily.Workers are reportedly being screened and tested as well as being paid wages and provided with food and other essentials.Hsu Li Yang, an associate professor and program leader for Infectious Diseases at the National University of Singapore, said: The important matter at hand is to swtly disrupt the chains of transmission in the dormitories, as well as in the rest of Singapore.Authorities have also tightened precautions with a four-week so-called circuit breaker, shutting down non-essential businesses and schools until May .The coronavirus had infected more than . million people and killed at least , since breaking out in December.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may social distancing waitrose
story: FORMER PM Theresa May sticks to the social distancing rules as she queues at a supermarket.Mrs May, , stayed two metres away from other shoppers as she waited outside her local Waitrose in Berkshire.She checked her mobile phone as she stood patiently in the queue before buying groceries in the store for approximately  minutes and leaving with a bag for le.Last week Mrs May shared her support for the Prime Minister who has been admitted to St Thomas Hospital where he is battling coronvirus.The former PM tweeted: My thoughts and prayers are with Boris Johnson and his family as he continues to receive treatment in hospital.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - title: cautiously safely kids back to school
story: THE question of when and how we re-open our schools is one of the key issues the nation will face when it steps carefully away from this Covid- lockdown.Based on the evidence, I believe that re-opening schools should be considered early in the exit strategy because it appears they play a relatively small role in transmissions.We tend to see children as excellent spreaders of bugs, and therefore ­closing schools seems to make sense.Yet research published earlier this week shows that this isn’t necessarily true for the Covid- virus.Almost everything we know about closing schools to stop disease outbreaks comes from influenza.Flu is a very dferent virus to coronavirus, and children drive much of influenza’s transmission.Coronavirus is less likely to affect children and young people.They rarely get very sick, and they mostly get very mild symptoms or show no ­symptoms at all.During the  epidemic caused by Sars — a cousin of Covid- — the data showed that schools and schoolchildren played no role in transmitting the virus.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here. The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealClosing schools harms our children in many ways.Yes, many of them are getting some online teaching  —  my -year-old had brilliant support from his school before the holidays.But we know that some schools are offering much less, and I worry that it is particularly the poorest children who are ­missing out.Children also benefit from school through contact with friends and adults outside their family.Plus there is support for mental health and even in the food that they might not get at home.School closures also force children together with parents at home for weeks on end.This can be a source of great bonding, but we know that, particularly for teens, being cut off from peer groups and other adults is not good for their development or mental health.The issue of forcing key worker parents to stay home has been largely solved during the pandemic by keeping some schools open just for their ­children.But for parents who are not key workers, being forced to look after ­children for weeks at home can prevent them earning an income.Closing schools has in the past been shown to increase social contacts between children outside school, and between children and adults looking after them, particularly grandparents, who are most vulnerable to this virus.Currently, those over  should be self- isolating away from children.But there are many grandparents who are under .Andschools stay closed while we allow adults to exit lockdown first, we risk an increase in contact between children and grandparents.One of the problems is that we tend to think of schools as being entirely closed or open.Our research showed that there are a range of potential options.It would mean a partial or staged re-opening with social distancing built in.The point of social distancing for schools is to reduce the number of children in contact at any one time.Ensuring that dferent school years don’t meet would be a useful start.So have half the school attend in the morning and half in the afternoon, close the playgrounds and stagger year-group start, end and break times so that ­dferent years never meet.Then ensure that dferent classes don’t meet.This could mean staggering start times by class or alternating the ways that classes enter and leave school, and ­keeping students in form classes for all their lessons.Schools could also look at how feasible social distancing is within classes.True, most British classrooms could not fit a metre between desks.However,only half of the school is attending at any one time, classes could spread out across more than one classroom.We also need very clear rules on when not to come to school with any ­symptoms, and the need for self-isolation at homeothers in the family had been ill will be required.Teachers need to be protected, as we protect those who ­continue to drive buses, man shopping centres and work in our health ­system.And teachers should be early in the queue for testing.This may all sound too dficult.However, we owe it to our ­children to examine all of these options.It could be done more easilywe had sufficient testing to know which children or teachers had had Covid-.But we may need to proceed ­without that, given what we are currently told about antibody-testing timescales.As mentioned, our schools are already ­partially open — for the children of key workers and vulnerable children.Let’s gradually increase that “partially” in a way that’s guided by science.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: families favourite pastimes coronavirus lockdown
story: A GRAN whose once-in-a-letime safari trip was ruined by coronavirus has instead created a ft elephant in the garden to ride on.Gail Blackwell, , had been planning a trip to Kenya with a friend when the Covid- pandemic struck.Luckily her green-fingered husband Eric, , was able to trim a bush in their garden to recreate Gail’s favourite animal - the African elephant.The couple, of Taunton, Somerset, have nicknamed the leafy green mammal ‘Nellie’ and even attached tusks which Eric picked up in an abattoir.Gail told The Sun: “I was so looking forward to going to Kenya but coronavirus has shut everything down so it seems the only animals I might see this year will be at Longleat.“I absolutely adore animals, elephants and giraffes are my favourite, I would love to see them in the wild and a trip to Kenya would have been a once-in-a-letime opportunity.”Part-time receptionist Gail and Eric, who is disabled and unable to leave their home, have been stuck indoors like millions of others during the coronavirus crisis.But their garden project has given the pair hours of entertainment.Gail added: “We have been coping with the virus and dreaming about the holidays.“Last year I was lucky enough to go away to Dubai, Turkey and I went on a Mediterranean cruise but this year I wanted to go a bit further, a safari has always been my dream but for the moment Nellie will have to do.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brits coronavirus restrictions vaccine developed 18 months
story: More severe restrictions will be gradually phased out but some, such as remote working and isolatingyou have symptoms of the virus, will remain in some form next year.Scientists say the discovery of a vaccine is the only genuine exit strategy from the virus, meaning the country will have to adjust to a new normal, the Daily Mail reported.According to the Mail, scientists expect a vaccine will take  months and some of the restrictions will remain in place until it the cure developed.But ministers are aiming to lt the more drastic lockdown measures in weeks, including the potential of opening up schools in June, and shops.Other non-essential services to be phased back in could include restaurants and pubs, although they may have to limit their numbers.An official also told Thelast night that social distancing measures may need to remain in place indefinitely while the country continues to keep the virus under control.Larger social gatherings may be the last to be permitted and those vulnerable to the virus asked to stay at home.It comes after foreign secretary Dominic Raab told the nation that it was too early to lt the lockdown, and that the country must stick to the plan in place.But the wait for a cure might not be too long, as some scientists are optimistic that a vaccine could be ready by September.Sarah Gilbert, professor of vaccinology at Oxford University, said she was  per cent confident that the vaccine being developed would work.The vaccine that her team is working on is set to have human trials starting within the next fortnight.Professor Gilbert told The Times: “I think theres a high chance that it will work based on other things that we have done with this type of vaccine.“It’s not just a hunch and as every week goes by we have more data to look at. I would go for  per cent, that’s my personal view.”The news comes after the daily death toll rose by  in the last  hours to ,– making it the biggest rise yet and more deadly Spain’s worst day of their outbreak.The grim figures from the Department of Health also reveal the total number of cases has risen to , – up from , infections yesterday.The majority of the daily death toll came in England, title: mum preparing dinner found smiley face inside pepper
story: Gemma Gillies, , was chopping up the p red pepper for the evening meal when she was stopped in her tracks by the unusual inside.She said: “It really made me smile – and made the family laugh too.“Everyone needs something to smile about at the moment.”Gemma and her carpenter husband Warren, , have had a tough time because they moved house to Saltdean, East Sussex, with their three sons, Beau, seven, Teddy, four and Fox, seven months, just before the lockdown.The mum of three said: “It has been overwhelming to move into a new place that needs lots of work doing but not being able to do it.“It’s little things like we can’t even get out to BQ to do any DIY jobs round the house.“And we really struggled to get food at the beginning because while everyone  was filling up their freezers we had to run everything down as we were moving.“And to top it all our youngest son got chicken pox shortly after the lockdown began.“It hasn’t been easy and we needed something to make us smile - so the pepper with the smiley face arrived just at the right time.”Counsellor Gemma spotted it as she was preparing a dish of salmon, couscous and vegetables.She added: “I have never seen anything like it. I thought ‘oh my gosh’ and called Warren through to see it.“We had a good laugh at it and the kids though it was really funny as well.“I should have kept it but it was my only pepper for the meal so after taking some photographs I had to chop it up.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: farmer confronts jaguar driver lockdown rules only towns
story: A JAGUAR driver got a good telling off from an angry Welsh farmer for breaking lockdown rules after he was confronted as he removed road closure signs.The flashy driver told the fuming farmer that lockdown rules only apply in large towns and cities after being blocked in.Farmer Eric Roberts was checking on his sheep near Aberffraw, north Wales, when he realised another vehicle was heading his way despite the lane being closed.Mr Roberts, , filmed the driver moving the road closure signs and cones before he confronted him about his actions near the beach at Porth Cwyfan.Mr Roberts asked the blue  Jag E-Pace driver who was dressed for the beach why he was ignoring the Covid- lockdown laws which have been in place for almost three weeks.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.The driver palmed off Mr Robertss genuine concerns and claimed the rules were set for big towns and cities and did not apply to rural areas such as Aberffraw.He said: “The rules were set for big towns and cities.Here in the rural environment it’s a completely dferent kettle of fish.“I’ve done contamination control. I know what I’m talking about.”Eric tells him: “The government says essential travel only. With a kayak  Do you think that’s essential ”The man then replies: “No, but I am working away from other people.”The man then says he lives in nearby Menai Bridge, where the tidal waters of the Menai Straits separate Anglesey from mainland Wales.Eric tells him to kayak closer to home: “What’s wrong with the Straits to go with that plastic thing you’ve got in the car  Nothing.” Eric says. “Why come here ”The man replies: “The current in the Straits is quite strong.”Eric adds: “Good - you’ll get a good paddle, it’ll give you good muscles.”The man then walked back to the signs and replaced them before Mr Roberts moved his car to let the Jag pass.Former Anglesey councillor Glyn Jones was alerted to the video footage and reported the matter to North Wales Police.Councillor Bryan Owen, who represents the area on Anglesey Council, added: I have reported this to the highways department this morning and they have been in touch with the police.North Wales Police has been contacted for comment.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappeal
