title: horse-riders-disappointed-loss-disability-centre
story: A HORSE-RIDING centre for people with disabilities has revealed the impact which closure has had on participants.The Tweeddale Rideability Groupwas forced to cease operating due to the coronavirus outbreak.Now that access to Crookston Farm, Peebles, has been blocked, riders and volunteers alike are very disappointed, a TRG coach told us.Katherine Carson said: "For a rider who isnt mobile, the ride could be the only time they get exercise, have the chance to breathe deeply, or sleep well."The TRG was due to begin its new season last month, with an expected  participants joining the sessions, led by  volunteers.Now, however, a single volunteer visits the site at a time to checks on the groups six horses.Ms Carson said: "Our participants are hugely disappointed. We were set to ride on March , and everyone was hyped up to start then."The volunteers had been getting the horses fit, with a large team normally taking the horses out for a ride. Its disappointing for volunteers as theyre not out with the horses as much."And the knock-on effect to our riders families is there too ndash they cant come to the sessions now and socialise."There are many benefits to being around the horses for both the riders and the team supporting them, according to Ms Carson.She said: "Its been proven that riding improves self-esteem, physical well-being, balance and helps riders set goals they can achieve their targets."The sense of being with horses, you improve your emotional well-being by being around them too. Theres also the benefits of being in the fresh air, working as part of a team, and having a common goal."We also have an educational programme to tie in with school teaching."The TRG team has worked hard to keep their community together during this time of social-distancing, even setting up online quizzes over email."We made the Clip Clop quiz," said Ms Carson. "I have  topics planned ndash not sure where well be after that."Feedback has been good so far. The quiz helps riders and volunteers to still feel like part of the community, its just a fun thing to keep us all part of the team."For more information on the Tweeddale Rideability Group, and for contact details, visit: www.tweeddale-rda.org.uk index.html or email, info@tweeddale-rda.org.uk

title: borders-man-helps-write-book-declaration-arbroath
story: AN INNERLEITHEN man has teamed up with Magnus Linklater and other distinguished figures to pen a book about one of the most signicant episodes in Scottish history.Malcolm Noble, , has written two chapters for a forthcoming publication about the Declaration of Arbroath.Mr Noble, a former headmaster, told us: ldquoI do rather a lot of writing but I would not describe myself as an expert [on the Declaration] ndash but I went to original sources as much as possible.The Declaration of Arbroath was a letter from the Scottish nobility to the Pope written on April , . The most-quoted line is a statement of Scottish independence.Mr Noble said the idea behind the forthcoming book, titled Conquered by No-one, was that  modern-day Scots would write about the  signatories to the Declaration.But Mr Noble himself is writing about two iniduals ndash William Ramsay, Earl of Dalhousie, and Malise IV, Earl of Strathearn.Authors of other chapters include Linklater ndash former editor of The Scotsman ndash and historian Murray Pittock.Mr Noble said: ldquoWhat I see as the underlying justication of this publication is to try to raise the profile of the Declaration of Arbroath as the most signicant document in Scottish history.Mr Noble said the -year-old document introduced the concept of government by consent to Scotland.ldquoI think thatrsquos the critical thing and why itrsquos the most important document in Scottish history, said Mr Noble.ldquoItrsquos recognised by the United States Senate as a contributing factor in the discussions that took place before the signing of the Declaration of Independence in  and itrsquos something that has had a status in the English-speaking world for quite a long time, but lost its traction in Scotland.Mr Noble said a recent survey of Scots found that around a third did not know much about the Declaration.The same poll revealed that many supporters of Scottish independence viewed the Battle of Bannockburn as more important, said Mr Noble.Asked for his own thoughts on Scottish independence, Mr Noble noted that he has lived in England for many years so would not be allowed to participate.Buthe were permitted, he would choose to remain in the United Kingdom, he said, albeit with the hope that a federal system would eventually emerge.Mr Noble said: ldquoI donrsquot think Scotland is going to stay as it is ndash I think decisions in the main should be made in Edinburgh but I believe in shared sovereignty and I think therersquos a value in being part of the UK.He added: ldquoIrsquom not yet persuaded that complete independence is in Scotlandrsquos interests but I certainly think we should be going a lot further in that direction than we are at the moment.Mr Noble is the chairman of the Royal Caledonian Trust, a charity that supports the education of Armed Forces children. He is immediate past president of the Caledonian Society of London.During his career as a teacher, he was headmaster of Bexley, London, which was then the largest school in the capital. When he was a schoolboy himself, he attended Peebles High School.Conquered By No One will be published later this month by Hammer  Mirror Books. The editor is Aberdeen University lecturer Neil McLennan.

title: borders-families-urged-stay-home-bank-holiday-weekend
story: A MINORITY of Borders residents continue to visit public places even when there is ldquoabsolutely no need.That is the view of Scottish Borders Council chief executive Tracey Logan, who urged households to respect lockdown guidance over the Easter Bank Holiday weekend.She said: ldquoLets be clear:you dont abide by this guidance you arent only putting your own le at risk - youre endangering the lives of other people.Warnings have also been issued by NHS Borders, Police Scotland and at least one local MSP.NHS Borders director of nursing and acute services Nicky Berry said: "We are at a critical stage in the fight to stop the spread of the coronavirus. Now, more so than ever, we need you to stay at home.Meanwhile, Chief Inspector Stuart Reid, whose remit is the Borders, said the ldquovast majority have made changes to their daily routines.But he suggested fines could be issued to those flouting the lockdown rules.ldquoOfficers and the public must take a common sense approach to this unique emergency. We will always encourage compliance but, as a last resort, we will use the enforcement powers which are in place, said Mr Reid.Borders MSP Rachael Hamilton called on constituents to avoid the temptation to roam the countryside.She said: ldquoWe are urging everyone to follow advice and exercise close to your home - non-essential journeys to the countryside are not permitted at this time.

title: latest-supermarket-restrictions-opening-hours-including-aldi-tesco-iceland

title: doctors-nurses-good-friday-procession-vatican
story: A pair of white-coated doctors who care for coronavirus patients participated in a torch-lit Good Friday procession, watched over by Pope Francis and held in a nearly empty St Peterrsquos Square instead of at Romersquos Colosseum because of Covid- safety measures.Francis presided over the late-night ceremony from the steps outside St Peterrsquos Basilica as the procession circled  times around the squarersquos central obelisk, slowly following a path marked by candles set on the squarersquos cobblestones.Besides the two doctors, who are part of the Vaticanrsquos health service, were a former prison inmate and the chaplain of prison in Padua, northern Italy, a unormed penitentiary police officer and nurses.The Way of the Cross procession, also known by its Latin name, Via Crucis, evokes Jesus suffering on his way to be crucied.In another break with tradition, Francis did not deliver a homily or offer remarks at the end of the -minute procession.vw,vw,px, px"A man holds the cross during the Via Crucis ndash or Way of the Cross ndash ceremony in front of St Peterrsquos Basilica Instead, for several minutes, he prayed silently, with his head bowed and hands clasped, before a wooden crucix which had been carried in Rome during the early th-century when the city was suffering through a plague.By then, the procession participants had left the square, and except for an aide, some camera crew and very few other Vatican personnel, Francis was left alone with his thoughts as he looked out across the vast empty space, where normally tens of thousands of people attend his audiences or outdoor Masses.During the procession, Francis listened to meditations being read aloud on the theme of suffering.While the Pope gave no speech at the end of the procession in St Peterrsquos Square, earlier in the day, in a phone chat with the host of an Italian state TV talk show, Francis offered thoughts about the Covid- outbreak.Francis said he thinking ldquoabout the crucied Lord as well as the ldquostories of the crucied in history, to those of today, of this pandemic. He went on to praise doctors, nurses, nuns and priests who ldquodied on the front lines, as soldiers, who gave their le for love.vw,vw,px, px"Pope Francis at a Good Friday service inside the basilica Earlier in the day, at a Good Friday service inside the basilica, the papal preacher said the pandemic has alerted people to the danger of thinking themselves all-powerful. During that service, in a sign of humble obedience, Francis prostrated himself for a few minutes on the basilica floor.With rank-and-file faithful not allowed into the basilica in accordance with virus containment measures, and as Francis listened attentively, the Rev Raniero Cantalamessa said that ldquoit took merely the smallest and most formless element of nature, a virus, to remind us that we are mortal and that ldquomilitary power and technology are not sufficient to save us.He added said that when the pandemic is over, ldquoing to the way things were is the lsquorecessionrsquo we should fear the most. He added that the virus broke down ldquobarriers and distinctions of race, nation, religion, wealth and power.The Vatican has said there are eight Covid- cases among Vatican city residents or employees.All of the Vaticanrsquos Holy Week ceremonies have been barred to the public, in keeping with Italyrsquos lock-down measures.Italy is living through a fth week of lockdown with at least three more weeks to go.The Colosseum Good Friday Way of the Cross procession normally draws tens of thousands of pilgrims and Romans who clutch candles and prayer books, while the Pope watches from a rise overlooking the ancient arena.But Italyrsquos stay-at-home measures sent tourists and pilgrims fleeing the country weeks ago, and Romans must stay at home except to go to essential jobs or do vital tasks like buying food or medicine..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Doctors and nurses in Good Friday procession at Vatican

title: spending-stays-local-coronavirus-alters-shopping-habits
story: Householdsrsquo spending on commuting costs has plunged by nearly % compared with a year ago, while fuel expenditure has fallen by %, according to a bankrsquos analysis of customer habits.Lloyds Bank compared trends under le on lockdown with a year ago, based on the debit card spending of its customers.People are also travelling around half the distance they would normally to spend.The median average distance people are travelling from home to use a debit card is down % from .km last year to .km.Cutting out non-essential travel is having a huge impact on where peoplersquos money is going.On March , spend on commuting costs was % higher than the same time the previous year. But by April , people were spending % less. And with more staying at home and car usage allowed for only limited purposes, spending on fuel had fallen by %.Lloydsrsquo data also showed volatility in supermarket spending throughout March and into April, reflecting an initial period of panic buying ahead of more stringent social distancing measures.Supermarket spending peaked on March , with a % spike in the amount spent compared with the same period in . Grocery spending then fell back and has since increased at a more gentle pace.Spending on electrical goods has also seen an uptick as people spend more time at home.But recreation spending has been hard hit. This includes spending on gyms, theatres and cinemas. Spending in this category fell by two-thirdscompared with a year earlier.Gabby Collins, head of payments, Lloyds Bank, said: ldquoThe trends that we have seen from our customers mirror what is being asked of all of us as a society. Marchrsquos spending data has shown a real sht in where our money is going during lockdown.ldquoWhile the more extreme spending behaviour we saw before the stringent social distancing measures came in already started to settle, itrsquos likely that spending will continue to reflect the unprecedented times we currently face. Over the coming weeks, many will be striving to find a balance in their finances..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Spending stays local as coronavirus alters shopping habits

title: sleep-boost-prestonpans-youngster-charity-dad-supported-lends-hand
story: Murray Scott, , liveswith broadcaster dad Mark,  mum Laura, , a supply classroom assistant at The Hub at Sandersonrsquos Wynd Primary School and sister Sophie, seven, a pupil at Prestonpans Primary School.Murray, who attends The Hub in Tranent, has a partially deleted chromosome which affects his development and brain.The condition also affects Murrayrsquos spine and hips he is unable to walk or talk, is doubly incontinent and is tube fed.Murray also has epilepsy and reduced vision, and for the first eight years of his le was unable to sleep through the night.Mark said: ldquoHe was born with it ndash itrsquos a chromosome disorder which neither of us [mum and dad] carries.ldquoHe would have been  months when we got the diagnosis ndash at that point he was one of  [sufferers] in the world.Murray is described by his family as a ldquoreally happy, content wee boy, and ldquoreally good natured. According to Sophie, he is ldquothe best big brother.Despite Murrayrsquos age, his parents said ldquohis brain has probably developed to that of a one-year-old, adding that he canrsquot pick things up and often does not know what to do with items hersquos given.It was Murrayrsquos physiotherapist at The Hub who recommended a sleep system: a series of blocks that help support his position while he sleeps.Murray had been sleeping with a large soft toy and pillow to prevent his leg getting stuck down the side of the bed.The youngster cannot adjust himself when he changes position during the night, which has been causing more damage to his spine and hips.It is hoped that the system, which can grow with him, will improve Murrayrsquos posture and reduce the need for surgery later on.Laura added: ldquoIt gives us a little bit of reassurance to know that hersquos not doing any more damage in his bed.Mark and Laura applied for funding to help purchase the sleep system from Cash For Kids ndash a charity for which Mark fundraised during his time working at Radio Forth.Mark said: ldquoIt is very dficult asking for charity help, especially when yoursquove raised a lot of money for that charity, but, at the same time, the sleep system costs about pound,.ldquoWe are delighted with it, itrsquos a huge help and makes a big change.Victoria Hendry, charity manager at Cash For Kids, added: ldquoWersquore absolutely thrilled to see what a dference the bespoke sleep system has made to Murrayrsquos quality of le.Donations to Cash For Kids can be made via cashforkids.uk make-a-donation

title: new-coronavirus-assessment-hub-opens-musselburgh
story: East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnership has opened a Covid- Assessment Hub in the town as part of NHS Lothianrsquos regional strategy for the management of patients needing assessment for possible coronavirus infection.Dr Alastair Clubb, East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnershiprsquos primary care clinical lead, said: "The team will assess people who have been advised to attend by NHSrsquos Call  service after phone triage."I want to make it very clear this is not a drop-in facility. The team does not carry out laboratory testing for coronavirus.""Patients who have symptoms suggestive of Covid- infection should follow the guidance and advice on self-care and isolation on the NHS Inform website ."It will take you through your symptoms and tell youyou are one of the small number of people who should contact NHSrsquos Call  service for further assessment over the phone."A very small number of patients assessed over the phone will be advised to attend one of the assessment centres in the Lothian region."Following these steps ensures that patients are safely assessed and allocated to the correct service for their needs."And it reduces the risk of transmitting the virus ndash the most important action we can all take during the pandemic."Patients attending the centre in Musselburgh will be greeted by the clinical team, who will already have all the relevant clinical information for patients.Most patients will be assessed without having to leave their car because the team is able to do this by going through a number of simple observations .It will usually not be necessary to give patients a full clinical examination, for example, a chest examination. Routinely carrying out clinical examinations could increase the risk of virus transmission.A small number of patients attending will be brought into the centre for further assessment and then directed towards the appropriate care, either at home or in hospital.Dr Clubb said: "The pathway for accessing the service is designed to ensure the safety of patients and staff alike. In the event of a le-threatening emergency, always call ."East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnershiprsquos Chief Officer Alison Macdonald added: "I would like to thank the team for getting the service up and running safely and quickly."We are well-placed to do this because we have been able to draw upon the expertise of the CWIC team, which has been developed over the last two years in our primary care service in Musselburgh."I would also like to re-iterate what Dr Clubb said about sticking to the rules."It is crucial that we all adhere to the guidance on contacting NHS rsquos  service ndash by doing this, you are doing your bit to help the NHS manage during these challenging times. Thank you."Thank you for reading this story. While I have your attention, I also have an important request to make.In order for us to continue to providetrusted local news, I am asking you to also please purchase a copy of our newspaperyou do not already.Trusted news has never been so important -and neither has your support.The Courier is not immune to the severe pressures brought on businesses up and down the land by the Covid- lockdown.Soyou are able to buy a copy for yourself -and maybe even for a neighbour too who is not able to get to the shops - then we would be very grateful.Andyou do wish to support us, please check with your local newsagent to seethey can deliver the Courier to you.There is also an E-Editionthat can be read on your PC, phone or tablet - just click the lsquoE-Editionrsquo tab under the Couriermasthead on the homepage of this website for more details.We want to be able to continue telling you all about our community heroes: our NHS staff, council staff, teachers, carers, shop owners and shop workers and the army of volunteers in every town and village helping the vulnerable.But we need your support to do so. If you can, please buy a paper. And keep well and keep safe.Thank you.Robbie Scott, Editor

title: coronavirus-team-working-hard-get-hot-meals-vulnerable-people
story: Our Community Kitchen, an intergenerational project designed to bring people together through a love of food, was launched two years ago.Meeting in Haddington Bowling Club, the group would regularly attract  people a week to its lunchtime events.However, with public gatherings banned during the coronavirus outbreak, the hard-working team has taken a dferent approach to ensure vulnerable members of the community receive tasty, hot meals.Elaine Gale, founder of the group, said: ldquoWe realised that hot food makes people feel good.ldquoWe have spoken to many people that come to us and asked them about that and the feedback we get is that it makes them feel good and a bit loved.ldquoWe felt we had a responsibility to do this and to turn around hot food deliveries.A team of volunteers are continuing to work at the townrsquos bowling club to produce hearty meals, including stovies, mince and tatties, and stews.The meals are then delivered to vulnerable people throughout Haddington, who have been referred to them by a range of local agencies, including GPs and social workers.Ms Gale, who hoped to see the project delivering  hot meals to  people a week, stressed the group was ensuring the meals were piping hot before a person was phoned to tell them that the meal was outside their door.She praised the community effort, including the bowling club, which is acting as a base, and the rugby club, which has offered its premises should the project need to expand.Ms Gale added: ldquoThe community has been phenomenal.ldquoThe community council bought us some foil containers and we have had lots of donations from the community. We have been inundated with volunteers and there are a tremendous amount of people coming forward.A trial run of the scheme took place on Friday, with a view to being up and running on a Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Friday.Ms Gale added: ldquoWe are overwhelmed with the outstanding support and kindness of our local community.ldquoItrsquos incredible seeing everyone working together ndash massive thanks to everyone who has been working hard to pull this together and to those who have already volunteered their help.The group has been a great success since it was launched in .Funding was secured last year to pay for a staff team to give the group stability and to look at ways as to how it could become more sustainable in the future.Before the shutdown, the group met in the bowling club on a Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday from .pm, with visitors receiving a three-course, freshly cooked meal, plus tea and coffee, for pound.Ms Gale said that came to a halt on March , as they were planning their St Patrickrsquos Day celebrations, due to the virus.She said: ldquoWe were just crying at the very thought of why we were there ndash to reduce social isolation ndash and realising people were going back into that place or worse.ldquoThen we started to think about the bigger picture and there are so many people out there and they are scared and worried.Thank you for reading this story. While I have your attention, I also have an important request to make.In order for us to continue to providetrusted local news, I am asking you to also please purchase a copy of our newspaperyou do not already.Trusted news has never been so important -and neither has your support.The Courier is not immune to the severe pressures brought on businesses up and down the land by the Covid- lockdown.Soyou are able to buy a copy for yourself -and maybe even for a neighbour too who is not able to get to the shops - then we would be very grateful.Andyou do wish to support us, please check with your local newsagent to seethey can deliver the Courier to you.There is also an E-Editionthat can be read on your PC, phone or tablet - just click the lsquoE-Editionrsquo tab under the Couriermasthead on the homepage of this website for more details.We want to be able to continue telling you all about our community heroes: our NHS staff, council staff, teachers, carers, shop owners and shop workers and the army of volunteers in every town and village helping the vulnerable.But we need your support to do so. so we can free up as many slots as possible for vulnerable people."NHS shopping hoursTesco has also introduced special shopping hours for NHS staff.Those eligible will be able to browse an hour before traditional shop opening hours on Sundays, and will have an hour between am and am to shop on Tuesdays and Thursdays at all stores except for Express stores, which are open to everyone during those times.In a statement, Tesco said: ldquoThey can come to our large stores one hour before the usual store opening time every Sunday, and will be able to browse the store and select their shopping before the checkouts open."All we ask is that they bring a form of ID with them to store, such as an NHS staff card.

title: new-45-contactless-card-limit-rolled-wednesday
story: The contactless card payment limit in shops hasincreased by pound, from pound previously,as part of measures to combat coronavirus.The new pound limit is three times the amount it was in .Trade association UK Finance, which represents the finance and payments industry, said the decision to raise the limit was made following talks with the retail sector. It follows similar increases recently made where in Europe.An increased limit was already being considered but the process has been accelerated as part of the industryrsquos response to Covid-.It will mean more payments can be made without the need to handle cash and it will also reduce the number of occasions when people need to input their Pin on a machine when making payments.With hundreds of thousands of terminals in the UK, UK Finance saidthe updating process wouldhappen gradually.The British Retail Consortiumhas said while the new contactless limit was nowoperational at some stores across the UK, it may be some time before it can be applied more widely.BRC head of payments policy Andrew Cregan said: ldquoSome shops will take longer to make the necessary changes, given the strain theyrsquore under.Some pound. billion was spent using contactless payments in , UK Finance figures show, up by % on the previous year.Gareth Shaw, head of money at Which , said: ldquoRaising the contactless card limit will be helpful for those shoppers and retailers who may want to handle less cash during the coronavirus crisis, but itrsquos also vital that vulnerable consumers do not end up without a way to pay for essential products and services.ldquoBoth the Government and retailers need to find a way to ensure that the millions of people who rely on cash, and may not have a bank card, can still pay for the basics they need during this dficult time.

title: prestonpans-mums-bear-hunt-idea-takes-off-around-world
story: It was organised by Jodie Donaldson who lives in the townrsquos Northfield Gardens with her partner Steven and daughter Lexii, a primary two pupil at Preston Tower Infant School.On why she started it Jodie, who is  weeks pregnant and currently studying at Edinburgh Napier University, said: ldquoMy daughter and her friends take teddy bears to school sometimes on a Friday, but of course they are not going to see each other.ldquoSo I thought why not put bears in the window and then they can see them when they are out on a walk and wave at them and say hello.Jodie then decided to set up a Facebook group last Mondayto encourage others to join in and put teddy bears in their windows to, in her words, ldquospread a little happiness and have something fun for the children.Jodie added: ldquoIrsquom pregnant at the moment and when this all happened I was kind of like lsquooh jeezrsquo.ldquoMy partner works in retail in a food shop so he has to go to work so Irsquom really concerned and needed something to keep my mind occupied, Irsquom such a worrier.She initially called it East Lothian Bear Hunt and saw images shared from all over the county.However, in three days over , people had joined the group and were sharing images from all over the world, as far away as New Zealand, Australia, South Africa and Canada.It was renamed lsquoThe Big Bear Huntrsquo and now has almost , members.Jodie said: ldquoIrsquom absolutely blown away. I was definitely not expecting it to get as big, but I guess that is how social media works.ldquoI canrsquot believe how much itrsquos spread. All I wanted was two or three people to smile and Irsquove managed to do just that.ldquoIrsquom quite surprised at how many people of all generations it has attracted. Itrsquos bringing them all back to their younger days.ldquoTherersquos some bears that have been posted in the group that are  years old and falling to bits, people are going up into their attics and bringing their own old ones down and are telling stories from when they were a child.ldquoTherersquos been over , comments so far and most of them are people sharing their childhood stories, they arenrsquot even talking about the virus.Jodie said that Lexii has been collecting beanie baby teddy bears since she was born so is ldquovery excited to get them all out.She added: ldquoItrsquos given her that distraction that she needed. Shersquos been out with Steven looking for more.Jodie is in talks with people who can knit bears and is hoping that a bunch can be made and auctioned off, she is hoping this will happen in the next couple of weeks.The bears are going to be NHS bears and will also be raising money for them.

title: tims-tales-isolated-not-alone
story: THIS virus has had a devastating effect on so many people in so many ways. Almost nobody has been untouched by it, although for some it has been more cataclysmic than others. But we are in this together, and it will be together that we pull through it.One of the real heartbreaking consequences of the lockdown has been the separation of families. Many grandparents now cannot see their grandchildren, or even their own children. Family of people who are ill cannot visit their loved ones. Each story has its own set of circumstances and sadly more is to come before it gets better.While we do need light-heartedness at this time, itrsquos also really important to acknowledge peoplersquos struggles. It was with gut-wrenching despair I realised a number of weeks ago that the arrival of Covid- in Europe was going to seriously affect so many families, my own included.I have five children, but my middle child, who is now  years old, has for the last eight years shared time between Scotland and Sweden.She went to school here until she was seven, when she began to attend school in Sweden. It was then that I had to adjust to the painful reality of less time with her, although I was still able to maintain regular time with her in Scotland and of course keep in daily touch.Itrsquos been an emotional rollercoaster, in which I have stories of me sleeping at airports, travelling through Scandinavian landscape at ungodly hours, and along the way meeting people who have helped and made a real dference. But itrsquos been worth it as it meant our blended family remained connected and my daughter hasnrsquot felt ided between two families but rather a full part of both.We were due to travel to Sweden this Friday andlater, but of course the flights were cancelled a couple of weeks ago. Explaining this to my daughter, and then not being able to say when we would be together was heartbreaking. I felt so helpless, unable to comfort her. Wersquod all counted down the days and now it seems it may be weeks, even months, before any reunion will be possible.I know that there will be families in similar or worse situations. My heart goes out to them all. My initial response to my situation was to close down with despair. The idea of not being with my child, for whom I was the equal main carer until recently, feels unbearable. Some friends have said, with good intentions: ldquoAt least shersquos safe.Yes she is, and I give thanks for that. But any loving parent facing long-term enforced separation from their child will understand the grief that such separation creates. It seeps into your being and makes it dficult to get through the day without having really dark moments. I tried to hide my emotions, but my loving and understanding we knows me too well yet she too felt helpless.There are moments in our lives when we are just overwhelmed by the impossibility of a situation and we just want to curl up and close down. I recently reached that point.Then my daughter asked me while we were talking online: ldquoI wish we could get a magic flying carpet or something dad, or ask the faeries to make a portal. She understood this wasnrsquot possible, but it was the wake-up call I needed. It made me realise I needed to get out of the pit of despair and, for her sake as well as mine, use my creativity to make that magic carpet, and that portal, to help us stay closely connected during this awful time.And the magic ingredient is stories. My daughter has always loved stories, and we have made many up together some of them have even been printed on this page. Now these stories help keep us connected and ease the pain of separation for us both.And so, with the help of technology, and, crucially, a good relationship with her mother, stories have begun to create a vital space for my daughter to be with her Scottish family, even when separated. We can all be together, even my grown-up daughters, who I miss even though they are isolating close by.We storytell to each other, make stories up and even share them in short films. Wee sister Skye, who is six and misses her sister like crazy, holds the tablet which she uses to speak to her, so they can be together while I tell stories and share riddles. We draw and add to the stories together, make fun dramas in which we film ourselves on phones acting out stories like Cinderella, and I have learnt to put wee films together which we can then watch together.Sharing stories like this has given extra meaning to our online communication. It takes us away from just asking ldquohow was your day  or ldquowhat did you do today  questions that often just seem to emphasise our current disconnection. Later, after this crisis is over, the wee films, the artwork and written stories will be memorabilia of this time our evidence that we remained close, even when forced apart.I write about this because I know there are parents and children out there in similarly dficult situations to say you are not alone in this and letrsquos be kind to each other and share the ways we keep ourselves connected. I also know others will have discovered better solutions, as Irsquom no technical wizard.Children are resilient, often more than their grown-ups are, but we need to help them manage this time emotionally, and when we canrsquot give them a hug or be physically with them in hard times, an inheritance of stories they can access can be a real support.I have often been less than enthusiastic about social media in the past, but right now people are discovering in this crisis it has become a leline in many ways.If you, or someone you know, are in a similar situation, please do get in touch. Letrsquos share our experiences, and understand that while we may be isolating, we are not alone.

title: european-stone-stacking-championships-dunbar-postponed
story: The European Stone Stacking Championships were due to take place between April  and , with a place at the World Rock Stacking Championships in Texas next year up for grabs.However, James Craig Page, creator and director of the festival, broke the news that the event, like dozens of others across the county, had to be postponed amid concerns surrounding coronavirus.Mr Page said: ldquoIt has been postponed but we are very hopeful that we will find another venue or be able to go ahead at a dferent time.ldquoHowever, for the time being we have to postpone.This year would have marked the fth year a stone stacking event had taken place in Dunbar event.Each year, it attracts thousands of people to the area, as well as competitors from throughout Europe.Mr Page spoke to the Courier upon ing from the World Rock Stacking Championships in the USA last month.Initially, he was keen to see the European event, which takes place at Eye Cave Beach, off Bayswell Road, take place.However, upon ing to British shores, he became aware of the state of the global issue.Speaking to the Courier, he said: ldquoWe were just waiting for word and advice but it became apparent when I got back how bad things were and that we needed to put it on hold.ldquoWe donrsquot want to be taking any risks with anybodyrsquos health and wellbeing. The event is all about promoting health and wellbeing.ldquoOur sponsors this year were the Edinburgh Science Festival and they have had to postpone their events, which is really disappointing because they had a great programme.One option would be to see the European Stone Stacking Championships take place in September at the Land Sand Stone Art Festival in Bridlington, Yorkshire.Mr Page stressed the event would be a loss to Dunbarrsquos economy. He said: ldquoI think it is one of the busiest times for the shopkeepers. It is really sad that this is affecting everybodyrsquos business.The competition is broken down into several dferent events, ranging from balancing as many stones as possible vertically to creating the most artistic display.The organiser said it was about more than simply balancing stones.He said: ldquoIt is all about getting people into nature and looking after your health and your mental health through interacting with nature and creativity.ldquoWe were expanding it to include a family event, which would have been really good.

title: online-karate-classes-helping-keep-east-lothian-residents-fit-lockdown
story: Chris Ewing usually hosts more than  karate classes each week throughout East Lothian, Midlothian and Edinburgh.But with schools and sports centres closing their doors, the karate teacher has moved things online.The man behind Chris Ewing Karateis offering one-month free virtual karate fitness classes in a bid to bring the community together.Mr Ewing, who is based in Tranent, said: ldquoWhen the schools and sports centres closed, I was trying to think of a way how I could keep the classes going and keep members going.ldquoWe have got a lot of members who are national team fighters and some are ranked in the top five in the world.ldquoI was looking online and a friend, Melissa Hand, saw an app called Zoom. She uses it for conference meetings and she came down and showed me how to use it.A few test runs later and -year-old Mr Ewing is now running a series of classes encouraging people to keep active.He told the Courier: ldquoI have even got the parents, mums and dads, all joining in with the classes. They are all staying active as well and sometimes there are five or six people all doing it at the one time.Classes take place throughout the day, with sometimes between  and  people all joining in.Anyone interested in taking part is able to receive a code and join the class.Sessions include padwork, cardio HIITand beginnersrsquo karate classes.Chris Ewing Karate Club trains in the style of karate known as Wado-Kai, which is a blend of traditional Japanese karate and jujitsu.On a competitive front, Mr Ewing said the coronavirus outbreak had also impacted upon some of the club members.Competitors are unable to reach tournaments in the Netherlands, Sweden and Croatia over the coming months, with Mr Ewing hopeful the club could get its money back.For more information, go to www.chrisewingkarateThank you for reading this story. title: call-urgent-review-east-lothians-school-catchment-areas
story: School catchment plans drawn up before new housing estates were built are splitting communities, with some families forced to walk past a new school to attend classes at an older one further away.A meeting of East Lothian Councilrsquos education committee heard calls for a review of catchment areas in Haddington and Musselburgh in particular, where it was claimed they were both out-of-date and bad for the environment.Haddington councillor Craig Hoy said that only some of the families moving into new housing near Letham Mains Primary School were within its catchment area, with others having to walk further to the townrsquos older school.He said: ldquoAt a time when East Lothian has declared a climate change emergency, it makes no sense that the children of some Gateside residents will be enrolled at Letham Mains Primary, while others have to travel across town to Haddington Primary.ldquoI would urge East Lothian Council to conduct a catchment review to recty this at the earliest possible opportunity.ldquoWe owe it to local parents to try and ensure their children are educated at the school nearest to where they live.ldquoA full review of local catchment areas would deliver this reassurance and support for local families.Councillor John Williamson, whose Musselburgh ward covers Old Craighall, said that in that community a child at ldquono  went to Campie Primary School in the town, while another at ldquono  was sent to Whitecraig Primary School.He added: ldquoThere is no direct route from Old Craighall to Whitecraig unless you fly.Lesley Brown, East Lothian Councilrsquos chief education officer, said a review of the entire learning strategy was under way.She told councillors it would include a review of catchment areas across East Lothian.Thank you for reading this story. title: plea-thank-posties
story: Georgina Bown, , has designed posters to put up in windows, thanking the local posties for their continued efforts.Georgina, who has won The Print Makers Print Award and exhibited in venues including the Royal Scottish Academy and Royal Society of British Artists, said: ldquoThe postal workers are working hard and canrsquot isolate like other key workers. My friend whorsquos a postie worked an -hour sht the other day.ldquoI think the public need to be conscious of the effects of ordering online while bored at home, and the additional pressure that puts on the postal and courier service.ldquoThe posties have got so much to do because everybodys at home ordering online, probably frivolous things that maybe they dont need, and its putting such pressure on them.ldquoI would also like to make people aware that posties arenrsquot provided with any protection for sorting and delivering post: no gloves, masks or sanitiser.ldquoThink of what theyre handling every day and the things they have to touch. All this stuff everybodys ordering online to entertain themselves at home.In addition to worries of postal workers being overworked is the concern about hygiene, Georgina said. ldquoThey could be passing [coronavirus] on, you know. It could be a health issue there. I think they need to be protected ndash so does everybody.Georgina added that the project would simultaneously entertain children and thank the posties:ldquoKids love to make posters, donrsquot they  So this is something they can do.She added: ldquoDonrsquot order unnecessary things -- think about it. They say its busier than Christmas.ldquoIf everybody could just curb that a little bit and take the pressure off the posties, that would be cool.

title: stenton-turns-little-piece-france-day
story: The idea came from the schoolrsquos principal teacher Tina Aitchison.All of the schoolrsquos  pupils spent four weeks planning the event and the cafe was held in early March in Stentonrsquos village hall.Pupils sent letters about their plan to local businesses inviting them to support the event.Letters received by Tesco and the Co-op led to the two stores donating all of the food and drink.The schoolrsquos pupils elected to raise money for two charities: World Wide Fund for Nature and Big Sleep Out.The pupils and staff dressed in French-themed and tricolour clothing, and had practised the language so they could speak French throughout the afternoon.Alongside tea and coffee, more than  people enjoyed a number of French-style pastries, bread and cheese.Teacher Sandra Macniven said: ldquoThe kids wanted to have a community event to bring everyone together.ldquoWersquore thinking of doing something like this every year now.ldquoThe children were involved in planning the whole event they did everything and we just supervised.ldquoItrsquos something a bit dferent than normal.ldquoIt also gives the whole school a chance to network with each other.ldquoWe were not expecting that many people to turn up but the community support in Stenton is great the community really supports everything the kids do.Representatives from Natwest had also visited the school to teach the children about budgeting. Each of the pupils had a specic role to play, including servers and greeters.Mrs Macniven added: ldquoIrsquod also like to thank the support staff for all of their help. We couldnrsquot do anything without them.ldquoThe children did an amazing job at serving and keeping everyone fed and hydrated.The pupils then performed The Very Hungry Caterpillar story in French and sang some French songs.Thanks to donations from all the guests, the school raised pound.Ronnie Taylor, headteacher at Stenton, Innerwick and West Barns Primary Schools, said: ldquoI think it was fantastic, I was really proud of the boys and girls.ldquoI think they worked really hard in the lead-up to what we were doing and itrsquos events like these that not only bring the learning of the curriculum together but bring the community together as well, which is really important in a place like Stenton.ldquoThe school is always supported we are very lucky we have an engaged community and I think the children rise to the occasion every time.

title: historic-stone-sculpture-revealed-haddington
story: The Free Gardeners, a fraternal society, was founded in the town in  and grew to have lodges all over the country, with more than , members in the Lothians alone.Now talented artist James Winnett has unveiled an intricately carved standing stone, inspired by the organisation, at Moncrieff Walk at the western end of the town.Mr Winnett said: ldquoI became fascinated with the story of the Free Gardeners, their rich symbolism, regalia and the artefacts they left behind.ldquoI wondered how a public artwork might make a tangible connection to these ideas, while referencing other links to local history and folklore.The Glasgow-based artist carved the seven-foot sandstone block as part of a public art commission supported by Persimmon Homes through East Lothian Councilrsquos Percent for Art scheme.The carvings on the stone include several Free Gardener symbols, such as the compass, set square and pruning kne, alongside depictions of the Tree of Le, lsquoJock in the Greenrsquo, the four rivers of the Garden of Eden, and Haddingtonrsquos emblematic goat climbing the Tree of Knowledge.There is also a reference to the former Mitsubishi factory ndash which stood on the site at Gateside before housing was built there ndash in the form of a beehive with three oak leaves above it, a nod to the origins of the Mitsubishi logo.Mr Winnett, who estimated he spent  days carving the stone, added: ldquoHalfway through the carving process, I turned the stone over and washed off the mud on the reverse face.ldquoIt was only then that I realised the whole surface was covered in plant fossils from more than  million years ago, which made a fortuitous link with the gardening theme!The -year-old artist visited Haddingtonrsquos John Gray Centre to find out more about the organisation.The Ancient Order of Free Gardeners, as they became known, bought a tenement in Haddington as their base, which became the Gardeners Arms pub.They ed like an early trade union or mutual aid society, supporting the poor while also holding floral exhibitions, tree planting ceremonies and colourful parades.Mr Winnett helped put the stone in place earlier this year and told the Courier: ldquoIt is a mixture of emotion at the end, partly a relief to get it in in one piece. It is a tricky thing to install.ldquoIt is a natural stone, itrsquos a funny shape, with flaws in the stone, and you have got a lot of preparation which goes into the foundations. It did not help we were doing it in some of the wettest weather.

title: old-motorbike-deliver-gin-lockdown
story: Emma Bouglet and Jo Brydie launched Fidra Gin, named after the island of Fidra in the Firth of Forth, in September .Now the fast-growing business, which is based near Athelstaneford, is looking to make deliveries by an unusual method of transport ndash a s Ukrainian Ural motorbike and sidecar.Jo said: ldquoIn these tumultuous times, we just felt this could bring some cheer into peoplersquos lives.ldquoAs movement is restricted and pubs and restaurants are closed, we wanted to help provide the means to a good night in.ldquoMany local food producers, shops and restaurants are also offering home delivery and we think this offers a fun and dferent way to support the local community and businesses during this dficult time.ldquoWe are continuing our offer of free UK delivery on all online orders and, for those local to us in East Lothian, your gin could be delivered by motorbike and sidecar!Orders will be left in a safe place to avoid direct contact with customers.

title: foreign-office-latest-advice-avoid-non-essential-travel-indefinitely
story: Initial advice was issued on March , urging everyone not to travel abroad for  days, but this has since been extended - with no end date in sight for when it will be lted.The latest new from the FCOmeans thatyou have a holiday booked -its now effectively cancelled.In the coming days -it islikely that your travel firm or airline will get in touch to discuss your options - and this may include rebooking your trip to take place ata later date.Vouchers and credit have also been offered by lots oftravel firms. Those not wishing to take that option are alsoentitled to request a refundyou want your money back.Those who are due to travel imminentlyhave been prioritised by travel firms.Many companies have reported beingflooded with calls in recent days, soyou are getting in touch, it may take ious attempts before you get through.In terms of what counts as essential travel has been made specic by the Foreign Office.A statement on the FCO website says: "Sometimes we say that only essential travel is advised."Whether travel is essential or not is your own decision."You may have urgent family or business commitments to attend to. Circumstances dfer from person to person."Only you can make an informed decision based on the risks."The updated advice from the FCO comes weeks after theUK went intolockdown, with people only allowed to leave home for several clear reasons.These consist of:- Exercise once a day- To shop for food,essentials and medicine- To travel to and from workyoure a key worker and your work cant be completed at home

title: tapestry-county-artist-mark-declaration-arbroath-goes-display
story: Mr Crummy, who designed the Scottish Diaspora and Battle of Prestonpans tapestries among others, first created the Arbroath Tapestry design two years ago.And after nearly , hours of needlework by teams in Angus, led by Arbroath-based Linda Walker, it has been framed in a stunning three  casing made from oak dating back  years which was taken from Robert the Brucersquos estate.The finished tapestry features in a documentary video released online to mark the anniversary on Monday, which features actor Brian Cox reciting part of the declaration and looks at its impact on Scotland.The documentary also features work by East Lothian artist Andrew Hillhouse, from Cockenzie, who passed away in .Celebrations which had been planned to mark the anniversary this week have been postponed until next year following the lockdown.However the documentary was released on time and showed the finished tapestry in its display case which will go on show at Arbroath AbbeyMr Crummy said he was delighted to be involved in the tapestry which is expected to go on display at Arbroath Abbey.He said: ldquoTo see how a small idea which was started by Linda Walker in Arbroath, has grown and made a huge impact already, even before it goes into the new visitors centre at Arbroath Abbey.ldquoIt has been a privilege, like all the tapestries to work with amazing stitchers. Without them their craft, creativity and generosity there would be no tapestry.The central  portrays Robert the Bruce and Abbot Bernard of Arbroath writing the Declaration while the two smaller  represent the role and influence of the Abbey within Arbroath.The left  features William I, founder of the Abbey, along with a fisherwoman to reflect the importance of local fishing industry.The right  represents the many trades which were involved in building and maintaining the Abbey and depicts two Scottish nobles setting sail to deliver the Declaration to Avignon.The Declaration of Arbroath was a letter sent from Scotlandrsquos nobles to Pope John in Avignon on April , .Widely acknowledged as one of Scotlandrsquos most important documents, the thanniversary of the Declaration of Arbroath has inspired Arbroath , a highly impressive six-month programme of special events.

title: tranent-legends-honoured-street-names
story: More than  houses are expected to be built to the south of the town at Windygoul South, between Ormiston Road and Elphinstone Road.Now, discussions are taking place to see well-known figures from Tranent recognised with streets named in their memory. Councillor Kenny McLeod, who represents the town on East Lothian Council, was among those backing the idea.Names being considered include the late Bobby Marr, who ran a greengrocer and florist on the townrsquos Winton Place for nearly  years Mary Johnstone, who was involved with the townrsquos community council and gala and died in  and Scott Glynn, who raised hundreds of thousands of pounds for good causes through a series of charity walks and passed away recently.Mr McLeod said: ldquoI hope it comes to fruition. We have got a bench for Bobby ndash anybody up to the age of , between  years old and , would know who Bobby Marr was.Fellow ward member Councillor Colin McGinn was also keen to see the idea explored further.He said: ldquoWe have had a wee bit of dialogue with council officials about the idea and I think it is a great thing to recognise some of the local folk that have made a dference and to chat about some of the names.ldquoThere are names that have been suggested by a number of people, like Bobby Marr, and Scott Glynn, who is particularly close to my heart.Mr McGinn said conversations would need to take place with the families of those suggested.And he felt it was a good way to ensure there was a connection between any new development and the existing town.He said: ldquoOur communities are all growing at ious times there are discussions that when communities grow you lose a sense of community.ldquoI believewe have got these names attached to developments it creates a link between the old and new.ldquoIt may generate some discussion about the community they are moving into.Work is already under way on housing to the south of Fleets View and west of Ormiston Road.David Forrest, chairman of Tranent and Elphinstone Community Council , also welcomed the idea.He said: ldquoI would like to see people recognised and streets named after them.ldquoA shortlist of three or four, including Scott Glynn, was mentioned.Mr Forrest noted there were already streets in the town, including Glennie Gardens and McNeill Walk, which bore the names of former residents.The community council chairman said: ldquoIt has gone on for years.ldquoPeople get remembered and streets are named after them and I donrsquot see why that should change now.

title: musicians-team-special-online-charity-gig
story: Anthony Neri, along with Daniel Fairgrieve, has been publicising live music in the area since  after forming the ELMGig Guide.However, with venues shutting their doors due to the coronavirus people cannot go out and do gigs.ldquoWe had people messaging us asking uswe could do anything with online streaming.ldquoObviously, over the years, I have got to know a lot of artists and venues and we have done interviews with people online and got quite a good network.For the last two weeks, musicians have streamed their performances through Facebook, with people making donations it is amazing.ldquoOne of the acts on Saturday he had people watching from New Zealand, Australia and the USA and he got an encore just by people chanting one more with a stream of messages coming title: knox-academy-staff-cook-storm-school-community
story: The school closed last month as the coronavirus crisis escalated.It is unknown when schools throughout East Lothian will open again but, ahead of the final school bell, staff were creating lsquomeal packsrsquo for some of the families in the school community.Steven Illingworth, depute headteacher, praised those involved for making scones, pizza and stuffed peppers.He said: ldquoHome economics teacher Sally Cochrane came up with the idea as the department had produce for forthcoming classes which would need to be used.ldquoA group of staff from across Knox Academy have come together to pre-prepare food and make meal boxes, complete with recipes, which have been offered to families who receive free school meals.ldquoWersquove also offered those families stocks of sanitary products to last them for the coming months and wersquove already had people coming into school to collect items.Among those pulling on their aprons at the school were Lisa Braid , Nick Groome-Vineand Shirley Gilliesin helping to create the tasty food packs.

title: nisa-north-berwick-bids-add-alcohol-deliveries
story: This is part of a planned wider refurbishment of both the inside and outside of the High Street store, which also includes a change to its layout.In an application submitted to East Lothian Council, the owners of the business are want to expand the size of their alcohol display by just over five square metres.Manz Ahmed, owner, said: ldquoThe main reason we are expanding our alcohol section is because we want to include more local produce and showcase the best of it.ldquoIf you look at the radius around the shop, the majority of our retail and supplies come from the local area.The owners of the High Street store also own another in the town on Lochbridge Road the proposed changes, applied for before the Covid- pandemic took hold, will not affect that store.The widened alcohol display would be located near the checkout area and the store has pledged high-quality CCTV in an aim to reduce crime and disorder.Staff within the shop and its delivery drivers would be trained to an appropriate standard.Nisa North Berwick has a home delivery service for its elderly and more vulnerable customers ndash this is expanded to all North Berwick, Gullane and Dirletonresidents, am-pm, in light of the coronavirus outbreak. title: east-lothian-council-easter-support-continues
story: Youngsters attending are being given the chance to learn cycling skills, gymnastics and arts and crafts.The children have access to a range of activities with fitness sessions emailed in from local clubs. Social distancing is maintained and hand washing is a regular part of the daily routine.Helping provide the activities ndash over what would have been two weeks of school holidays ndash alongside Active Schools are the outdoor learning service, libraries, the education and ranger service as well as the lsquoCan Dorsquo playscheme.Children at the four Easter holiday hubs are also being given the chance to take part in Bikeability Scotland training, a programme developed and funded by Cycling Scotland to help young people develop cycling.East Lothian Council decided after consulting with parents to keep the hubs in Musselburgh, Tranent, Haddington and Dunbar open, closing those in Prestonpans and North Berwick.Last week, about  children attended the six hubs and the council expects about  to attend the four that stay open over the holidays.Lesley Brown, the councilrsquos chief operating officer for education, said:ldquoThis is an extremely dficult time for families. As the end of term approached, staff volunteers came forward to maintain provision over the Easter holidays. While this is not a situation anyone would have wanted, the arrangements we have put in place will provide assistance to key workers at this dficult time.Youngsters attending the Musselburgh hub took part in cycling activities and games including slaloms, lsquocycle the tightropersquo and emergency stops on Monday.Some of the groups have been decorating their classroom doors with team names. Teams can earn points for imagination, social distancing, having fun and positive behaviours such as good manners.Mark Unwin from Active Schools said: ldquoThe kids were loving the chance to learn new skills and explore the school grounds on the bikes provided by the Bikeability programme and Sparewheels..

title: thousands-meals-delivered-incredible-project
story: Fundamental Foods has launched a crowdfunding page to help it continue the work of its dedicated team who are running two pantries in Prestonpans and Tranent and making deliveries to people in Tranent, Elphinstone, Cockenzie and Port Seton and Prestonpans.Lorna Bellany, from the project, which is run by Pennypit Community Development Trust, said they had delivered , meals last week with up to , expected to be delivered this week.And she revealed the desperate situations some people had been living in as they tried to self isolate or stay at home.She said: ldquoWersquove had some amazing feedback from people from all backgrounds: we even found out that an elderly couple had only eaten corn flakes for two weeks prior to our support and therersquos many iniduals that were skipping meals as they didnrsquot know how long theircupboard stockswould last.Fundamental Foods is estimating it is now making more than  deliveries every day, not including the meals.The pantries, which are run out of the Pennypit Centre, in Prestonpans, and St Martinrsquos RC Church Hall, Tranent, also provide people with food bags, recipe bags, and toiletries as well as hot meals and pre-cooked meals.They received donations from local restaurants and food outlets who closed following the lockdown however stocks are diminishing and restrictions on shopping have not helped.Lorna said: ldquoWe are currently using donated foods to give out that we get through Fareshare, from the local store surplus, community donations and we also got a lot of donations from restaurants and food outlets that were closed after government advice which was hugely helpful.ldquoOur food donations are really kind however with shop restrictions in place and stores not having a lot of surplus - our stocks are diminishingquickly.ldquoWe are working closely with thelocal community councils, housing associations, GPs, day centres and health visitors to gain more referrals and reach out to those in need.Ruth Davie, Pennypit Trust manager, who is overseeing the Tranent pantry operations at the moment, has issued an appeal for donations to help continue the work.Donations of food toiletries can be dropped off at both pantries between am and pm.To help fund the project go to www.crowdfunder fundamental-foods

title: first-minister-nicola-sturgeon-quizzed-schoolchildren-coronavirus
story: Nicola Sturgeon took part in an online question and answer session for children, with a dozen youngsters from across the country given the chance to ask a question about the global pandemic in a video released on Tuesday.Among them were Ember Quinn, Nuala Coates Auden, Millie Holland and Jasper Allison, all from Dunbar Primary School.Parent Club ndash an online information and support hub for parents in Scotland ndash invited children to submit their questions to the First Minister.Five-year-old Ember, -year-old Nuala, -year-old Millie and six-year-old Jasper asked, lsquoHow did the coronavirus start rsquo, lsquoWhat can I do to stop the coronavirus rsquo, lsquoDo you think the schools will reopen again before the start of next term rsquo and lsquoCan you give the homeless people a house while the coronavirus is here rsquoAddressing these questions alongside others including ndash lsquoHow does coronavirus spread rsquo, lsquoWhy can I not see my granny rsquo and lsquoWhen can I see my friends again rsquo ndash the First Minister spoke about the need for proper hand washing frequently, the symptoms to be aware of and explained the importance of staying home, minimising contact with other people and thanked families across the country for everything being done to help stop the spread of the virus.Said Ms Sturgeon: ldquoWe have introduced lots of changes to try and limit the spread of the virus and children across the country are having to accept a very dferent way of le right now, without much time to understand why.ldquoI know that some will be thinking itrsquos scary and I understand that.ldquoWe want to help them at this dficult time by reassuring them that itrsquos okay to be feeling this way and to answer some of the key questions they have.ldquoIt was a very important QA for me and I did my best to give them all the answers they need in simple terms.

title: countryside-plans-branded-over-development-east-lothian-council
story: Plans to build the new houses at the site, next to Longnewton Farm, near Gford, were put forward along with three new homes being created within the restored steading building.They were rejected by planning officers as against the councilrsquos countryside policy.And at a Local Review Body meeting of East Lothian Council, an appeal against that decision was also rejected.It was revealed the site had been given the go-ahead for  smaller homes to be built there in the past however, they were planned to be constructed within existing buildings.The new proposals would see a number of buildings on the site demolished.Agents for the application said they approached East Lothian Council in  with a pre-application enquiry but were told the councilrsquos countryside policy was against new builds unless they met strict exemptions, and were advised to consider converting the buildings on the land.However, they said no consideration appeared to have been given to the previous approval of  houses on the site.They warned there was a ldquovery real risk of losing attractive traditional agricultural buildings which are understood to date from the thcentury,further deterioration takes place due to a viable and marketable development solution not being found.However, at the review body, Councillor Lachlan Bruce said a balance had to be struck between the importance of saving historic buildings and protecting the countryside.He said: ldquoI think in this case the officer was right to say that the balance here is out of kilter.Mr Bruce added that the councilrsquos countryside policy was one of the most important they had, to protect rural parts of the county.Councillor Norman Hampshire, who chaired the review body, acknowledged that the local authority had supported developments across the county which had seen old steading buildings restored.He said: ldquoLooking at the site, the steading is in really bad condition and needs work done to it or it will be lost forever however, I think this project is an over-development of the site.The review body unanimously rejected the appeal.

title: walk-scott-foundation-makes-18-000-charity-donation
story: East Lothian Foodbank, Wee Red Upcycles and Home-Start East Lothian have joined together in a new project to help as many families as possible during the pandemic.The Walk With Scott Foundation board were discussing how they could support dferent areas of the county.They decided to directly support causes that would have the greatest impact across the whole of East Lothian and donated the money to the project.Colin McGinn, ward councillor and board member, said: ldquoThe foundation is very keen to help East Lothian families and we want to make sure we have a big impact on the county.ldquoWe are tapping into their experience, knowledge and network to make sure we have that impact.ldquoWe were deciding on what our next project would be but no one knew this would happen.ldquoTherersquos going to be an increased need for lots of services like the foodbank and Home Start so the damage is going to begreat the need for them is immediate.ldquoThis money will allow them to fund over their agreed level and to expand to [fulfil] the needs of workers worrying about funds.He added: ldquoWhen Scott [Glynn] started the charity he was very clear he wanted to help local groups, specically groups who have already started and had groundwork in place but needed an extra push over the line.ldquoWe know that Scott would be  per cent behind this.ldquoWe desperately hope that this need is not there in a few months and hope that this will make a dference.The money will help buy a number of items such as food, drink, activities for children and other essential items.The items will be sourced locally to help support local traders during the current crisis.The Walk With Scott Foundation was started by Scott Glynn seven years ago.He died on New Yearrsquos Day aged .

title: coronavirus-leaves-dunbar-woman-stranded-australia
story: Lucy Hall spent a year planning the trip of a letime, where she hoped to work with an animal charity.However, less than a month after arriving in Australia, the former Dunbar Grammar School pupil found herself without a job and unable to fly home due to the coronavirus outbreak.She said: ldquoThings were going great! I managed to find a job within the first week of being here so I was off to a good start.ldquoI had found numerous charity events and environmental gatherings I wanted to take part in and have applied to volunteer in an animal welfare charity shop.ldquoI was really happy and content.ldquoThe coronavirus has had a massive effect on my time here.ldquoI am very lucky that I have a safe place to stay but I have lost my job due to it and so now have no way of earning money.ldquoLike the rest of the world, we are now progressing into lockdown here and everything is closing so I cannot partake in any of the things I had planned or go anywhere I had wanted to go.ldquoMuch like thousands of other travellers, my big plans have come to a complete halt and Irsquom doing the complete opposite of what I had imagined Irsquod be doing.Lucy, , who is living in Cha Heights, in the outer suburbs of Melbourne, started planning her trip to Australia a year ago.She has family in the country and planned to travel around Australia before deciding whether tohome to Scotland or to extend her visa.Lucy said: ldquoI have an uncle in Australia so Irsquove always liked the idea of coming to visit since I was young but my final decision on coming was made in April  this is when I purchased my visa!ldquoMy original plan was to travel around Australia and work while I also did some charity animal welfare-based volunteering.ldquoI raised some money before coming here to allow me to volunteer doing things such as beach clear ups, conservation work and volunteering at animal reserves.ldquoI was looking forward to meeting new people and potentially building a le out here.Now, without a job, she is unable to earn money or buy a plane ticket back to her home on Dunbarrsquos East Links Road.She stressed there were many people much worse off than herself and that she at least had family taking care of her.However, she was concerned about her family at home and how they were coping with the coronavirus.She said: ldquoMy plans are being put on hold for now whilst I figure out what my next steps are.ldquoMy main concerns are being sensible and staying safe whilst ensuring my family back home are coping as well.ldquoI had a flight booked to come back to Scotland last week but it unfortunately got cancelled due to airports closing their doors to non-nationals.ldquoI guess Australia has been impacted much like any other country at the moment.ldquoEverything is slowly shutting down, people are losing their jobs and there are more and more rules being put in place each day to minimise the risk. Itrsquos a very uncertain and frustrating time for travellers trying to get home.

title: public-can-report-businesses-not-sticking-covid-19-guidelines
story: East Lothian Council says environmental health officers across Scotland now have new responsibilities to ensure appropriate public health measures are being followed during the Coronavirus pandemic.And it said any shops which could not comply with the social distancing measures required will be forced to shut down.The new Health ProtectionRegulations  have given additional control to councils and police to close premises.Councillor Norman Hampshire, environmental spokesperson for East Lothian Council, said enforcement remained a last resort for environmental health officers.And he urged people to report any business where guidelines are not being observed.He said: "East Lothian Council in all cases will seek to encourage businesses to comply with the measures through stressing the risks to the public and the NHS.ldquoFormal enforcement will always be the last resort where businesses fail to comply or where social distancing requirements are compromised, putting public health at risk. This approach mirrors Police Scotlandrsquos lsquoPolicing by Consentrsquo policy.ldquoWe are asking local residents thatthey have any concerns regarding social distancing measures either not in place or not being observed in shops to email ehts@eastlothian.gov.uk.ldquoThe Environmental Health and Trading Standards Team will then allocate an Officer according to the nature of the complaint.
